questions.question: Identify the element with an electronic con ﬁ guration 2,8,1 from among the following options.
questions.explanation: Sodium (Na), with an atomic number of 11, is a soft, silvery-white, highly reactive metal. It belongs to the alkali metal group. Chlorine (Cl): Atomic number 17; con ﬁ guration 2,8,7. Hydrogen (H): Atomic number 1; con ﬁ guration 1. Magnesium (Mg): Atomic number 12; conﬁ guration 2 ,8, 2.

questions.question: The number of atoms in exactly 12 g of carbon-12 is known as:
questions.explanation: Avogadro’s constant. The number of particles (atoms, molecules or ions) present in one mole of any substance is ﬁx ed, with a value of 6.022 × 1023. This number is called the Avogadro Constant or Avogadro Number, named in honour of the Italian scientist, Amedeo Avogadro. Rydberg formula - It is used to describe the wavelengths of spectral lines and was formulated by the Swedish physicist Johannes Rydberg. Planck's constant - It is the physical constant that relates the energy carried by a single photon to its corresponding frequency. Faraday’s constant - It is deﬁ ned as the magnitude of the electric charge carried by one mole of electrons.

questions.question: JJ Thomson is known for developing which model in 1898?
questions.explanation: Plumpuddingmodel. According to this model, the atom was thought to consist of a positively charged sphere with negatively charged electrons embedded in it, similar to plums in a pudding. This model was later replaced by Rutherford's nuclear model of the atom. The gold foil model was proposed by Ernest Rutherford in 1911. The double-slit experiment conducted by Thomas Young in 1801. The oil dropexperiment was performed by Robert A. Millikan and Harvey Fletcher in 1909.

questions.question: Which of the following statements are correct postulates of Dalton’s atomic theory? A.All matter is made up of atoms. These atoms participate in chemical reactions. B.Atoms might be created or destroyed during a chemical reaction. C.Atoms of different elements vary in mass and chemical properties. D.Compounds are combination of atoms in the ratio of whole or fractional numbers. E.A compound will always have constant relative number and kind of atoms.
questions.explanation: A, C, E. Dalton's atomic theory, proposed by John Dalton, states that all matter is composed of extremely small particles called atoms. In chemical reactions, atoms are combined, separated, or rearranged. Compounds are combinations of atoms in ﬁx ed, whole-number ratios, not fractional numbers.

questions.question: The space- ﬁ lling model emphasises the relative size of each atom based on its _______.

options.c: ﬁx ed radius for all atoms

questions.explanation: van der Waals radius. It represents the overall size of the atom which includes its valence shell in a nonbonded situation. Further, the van der Waals radius is half of the distance between two similar atoms in separate molecules in a solid. The contribution from each atom is called the covalent radius of that atom. ionic radius is the distance between the nucleus of an ion and the outermost shell of the ion.

questions.question: Ernest Rutherford used about ______ thick gold foil for alpha scattering experiments.
questions.explanation: 1000 atoms. Ernest Rutherford studied the atom by projecting alpha-particles on a thin gold foil. He discovered that the atom consists mostly of empty space and a small, dense, positively charged nucleus at the center. This discovery improved the understanding of atomic structure.Q.7. How many electrons does a hydrogen molecule have in its K shell? SSC CPO 27/06/2024 (2nd shift) (a) 4 (b) 2 (c) 1 (d) 3 Sol.7.(b) 2. A hydrogen molecule (H2) consists of two hydrogen atoms, each with one electron. Since hydrogen has only one electron in its K shell, a hydrogen molecule will have two electrons in total in the K shell, one from each atom.

questions.question: The signs of charges of electron, proton and neutron are_____, respectively.
questions.explanation: negative, positive and neutral. Protons and neutrons are collectively called nucleons. For an atom's electronic stability, the number of electrons must equal the number of protons, as protons have a +1 charge and electrons a –1 charge. Neutrons, in contrast, are neutral and carry no charge.

questions.question: What is the number of protons present in beryllium?
questions.explanation: 4. Beryllium (Be) is one of the lightest metals and has one of the highest melting points among the light metals. Louis Nicolas Vauquelin discovered beryllium in the oxide form in both beryl and emeralds in 1798. Beryllium : Neutrons (5), Electrons (4), Atomic Number (4), Mass Number (9), Electronic con ﬁ guration (1s22s2).

questions.question: Which is the weakest intermolecular force, considered as the Van der Waals force, often found in halogens, noble gases and other non-polar molecules?
questions.explanation: London dispersion forces. These forces are attractive and their energy is inversely proportional to the sixth power of the distance between the two particles. These forces are signi ﬁ cant only at short distances (~500 pm) and depend on the polarizability of the particle.

questions.question: In ethylene (C 2H4), hybridisation of carbon atoms is:
questions.explanation: sp2.In this hybridization, one 's' and two 'p' orbitals combine to form three new sp² hybrid orbitals, all with the same shape and energy. Hybridization refers to the process of merging two atomic orbitals to create new hybridized orbitals.

questions.question: Identify whether the given statements about ionisation energy are correct or incorrect. Statement A: The ionisation energy of an atom is the amount of energy that is required to remove an electron from a mole of atoms in the gas phase. Statement B : The ionisation energy increases from top to bottom in groups and decreases from left to right across a period.

options.c: Both Statements A and B are correct
options.d: Both Statements A and B are incorrect

questions.explanation: Only Statement A is correct. The ionization energy decreases from top to bottom in groups, and increases from left to right across a period. Thus, helium has the largest ionization energy, while Caesium has the lowest.

questions.question: In which year did Carl Anderson discover a positively charged particle called "positron' whose mass appears to be equal to the mass of an electron?
questions.explanation: 1932. Electron - J.J. Thomson (1897). Proton - E. Rutherford. Neutron - James Chadwick (1932).

questions.question: Which are the four quantum numbers for an electron present in 4f orbital ?
questions.explanation: n = 4, l = 3, m = + 1, s = + .1 2 There are four quantum numbers: Principal (n) - It refers to the electron shell with the most electrons, giving the electron's likely distance from thenucleus. Azimuthal (l) - It is de ﬁ ned as the determination of the shape of an orbital.Magnetic (m) - The subshell's overall number of orbitals and their orientation. Spin (s) - The values of n, l, and m lhave no bearing on the electron. The 4s subshell contains 1 orbital and can hold up to 2 electrons. The 4p subshell contains 3 orbitals and can hold up to 6 electrons. The 4d subshell contains 5 orbitals and can hold up to 10 electrons.The 4f subshell has 7 orbitals and can hold up to 14 electrons.

questions.question: The correct electronic conﬁ guration of Cu is :
questions.explanation: [Ar]3d104s1.Copper (Cu) - Atomic number (29), Electronic conﬁ guration - 1s² 2s² 2p⁶ 3s² 3p⁶ 4s¹ 3d10or [Ar]3d104s1.

questions.question: What does it mean when an object has a positive charge ?

options.a: It has more electrons than protons
options.b: It has more protons than electrons
options.c: It has more neutrons than electrons
options.d: It has more neutrons than protons

questions.explanation: An electron is a negatively charged particle and protons are positively charged particles.

questions.question: Which of the following pairs of 'number - composition' is correct? I. Atomic number - number of protons II. Mass number - Sum of number of neutrons and protons
questions.explanation: Both I and II. As atomic number increases, subsequently mass number also increases.

questions.question: Which of the following is the correct representation of number of atoms?
questions.explanation: ( ) × Avogadro𝐺𝑖𝑣𝑒𝑛 𝑚𝑎𝑠𝑠 𝑀𝑜𝑙𝑎𝑟 𝑚𝑎𝑠𝑠 number.Avogadro number: 6.022 × 10²³.Molar mass of a substance is the mass (in grams) of one mole of the compound.

questions.question: What is the maximum number of electrons that the third orbit or M-shell can have?
questions.explanation: 18 . The maximum number of electrons accommodated in a shell based on principal quantum number (n). It is represented by the formula 2n2. K shell, n = 1, Max Electron = 2 × 12= 2. L shell, n = 2, Max Electron = 2 × 22= 8. M shell, n = 3, Max Electron = 2 × 32= 18. N shell, n = 4, Max Electron = 2 × 42= 32.

questions.question: Which of the following statements is NOT correct regarding Rutherford's nuclear model of an atom?

options.a: The size of the nucleus is very large as compared to the size of the atom.
options.b: The electrons revolve around the nucleus in circular paths.
options.c: There is a positively charged centre in an atom called the nucleus.
options.d: Nearly all the mass of an atom resides in the nucleus.

questions.explanation: According to Rutherford’s nuclear model of an atom, nucleus is very small in size as compared to the size of the atom. Rutherford explained the revolving of electrons around the nucleus, however, he did not mention how the electrons were placed inside, which ended up making Rutherford’s model an incomplete model of the atom.

questions.question: Which of the following pairs of 'elements - valency' is correct? I. Boron - 2 II. Fluorine - 3
questions.explanation: Neither I nor II. Valency - Combining power of an element. Valency of some elements : Aluminium (+3), Boron (+3), ﬂuorine (-1).

questions.question: Which theory discusses the relationship between ligand bonding and degradation of d orbitals in metal complexes and the geometry of metal complexes and the splitting of d orbitals?
questions.explanation: Crystal ﬁeld theory: (1929, developed by physicist Hans Bethe) describes the breaking of orbital degeneracy in transition metal complexes due to the presence of ligands.

questions.question: What is the atomicity of Phosphorus?
questions.explanation: Tetra-atomic.Atomicity is the total number of atoms present in a molecule. Polyatomic (composed of three or more atoms). Phosphorus was ﬁrst made by Hennig Brandt in 1669.

questions.question: Which formula is used to represent the three-dimensional structures of molecules using a two-dimensional surface like a sheet of paper or a computer screen ?
questions.explanation: Dash-wedge formula. Bond - line formula is used for every bond represented as a line in a zigzag manner.

questions.question: What is the product formed when zinc and sulphuric acid react?
questions.explanation: Zincsulphate. Zinc reacts with dilute Sulphuric acid to form Zinc sulphate and Hydrogen gas is evolved from the reaction. This is a single displacement reaction of a non-metal by a metal. Both metals and nonmetals take part in displacement reactions. Zn (s) + H2SO4(aq)→ZnSO4(aq) + H2(g).

questions.question: Which gas is evolved when iron and water react ?
questions.explanation: Hydrogen. When iron (Fe) reacts with water (H 2O), the reaction produces hydrogen gas (H2). This is an example of a metal- water reaction. Reaction: Fe (iron) + 2H2O (water) → Fe(OH) 2(ferrous hydroxide) + H 2 (hydrogen gas).

questions.question: Which of the following gases plays an important role in welding titanium, aluminium, stainless steel, and magnesium ?
questions.explanation: Argon (Ag): a chemical element with atomic number 18. It is a noble gas, meaning it is inert and does not react with other substances.

questions.question: What is the name of the seventh most abundant metal in the earth's crust, which is derived from the medieval Latin word 'Kalium' ?
questions.explanation: Potassium. It makes up 2.4% by mass of the Earth crust. Aluminium is the most abundant metal and Oxygen is the most abundant non-metal found in the earth's crust. Eight most abundant elements in the Earth's crust are Oxygen (O), Silicon (Si), Aluminium (Al), Calcium (Ca), Iron (Fe), Magnesium (Mg), Sodium (Na), and Potassium (K).

questions.question: An image of which of the following elements is shown by the map of Cyprus from which the element got its name ?
questions.explanation: Copper (Cu, Atomic no 29). It is a good conductor of heat and electricity. It is in group 11, period 4 and block ‘d’ of the periodic table. It was the ﬁrst metal used by man on earth.

questions.question: Which radioactive isotope has a half-life of 5770 years, which is commonly used to estimate the age of organic materials such as paper and parchment ?
questions.explanation: 14C - It is an unstable and weakly radioactive isotope of carbon. Three Natural isotopes of carbon :12C, 13C and14C.

questions.question: Which metal ion released from the tannery industry causes acute water pollution?
questions.explanation: Chromium (Cr). Tannery Wastewaters: It contains Hairs, proteins, acids, alkalis, chromium salts, sulphides, chlorides, tannins, solvents, dyes.

questions.question: From which Latin word is the S block element calcium derived ?
questions.explanation: Calx (calcium hydroxide) . Formula - Ca(OH)2. It is used in industrial settings, such as sewage treatment, paper production, construction, and food processing. Calum (calcium carbonate): Formula - CaCO3.

questions.question: Which element of Group 17 has two isotopes of masses 35 and 37 amu with average abundance of 75.77% and 24.23%, respectively?
questions.explanation: Chlorine. Element of Group 17 : The halogens are located on the left of the noble gases on the periodic table. These ﬁv e toxic, non-metallic elements make up Group 17 of the periodic table and consist of : ﬂuorine (9, F), chlorine (17, Cl), bromine (35, Br), iodine (53, I), and astatine (85, At).

questions.question: Which among the following alloys is a combination of gold and silver?
questions.explanation: Electrum .Someotheralloys: Steel (Carbon and Iron). Stainless steel - (Iron with Chromium and Nickel). German silver - (copper, zinc and nickel). Rose Metal - (Bismuth, Lead and Tin). Gun Metal - (Cu + Sn + Zn + Pb). Dutch metal- (Cu and Zn). Constantan (Eureka) - Alloy of 55% Copper and 45% Nickel. Solder - It is made up of Tin and Lead.

questions.question: Which of the following is a non - metal that can exist in different form?
questions.explanation: Carbon (C) . Atomic number- 6. Belongs to the 14th group. It is a tetravalent which makes a chemical bond with four electrons. Each form of carbon is called an allotrope.

questions.question: What is the characteristic of isotopes ?

options.b: Same atomic number and different mass number
options.c: Same atomic number and same mass number

questions.explanation: Isotopes – Atoms of the same element that have the same atomic number, but different mass numbers. For example, the hydrogen atom has three atomic isotopes, namely protium (1 1H), deuterium (2 1H or D) and tritium (3 1H or T). The atomic number of each is 1, but the mass numbers are 1, 2 and 3 respectively. Isodiaphers - They are atoms of different elements that have the same difference between the number of protons and the number of neutrons. Example : Carbon-12 and Nitrogen-14.

questions.question: Which of the following metals is always a component in an amalgam?
questions.explanation: Mercury. Amalgam is an alloy of mercury with one or more metals. The most common amalgam is dental amalgam, which is used to ﬁll cavities in teeth. Dental amalgam is a mixture of mercury, silver, tin, and copper.

questions.question: Oxides of ____ and ______ dissolve in rain water and form acids which are called acid rain.
questions.explanation: Sulphur,nitrogen.AcidRain- When the pH of the rain water drops below 5.6, it is called acid rain. Acid rain damages buildings and other structures made of stone or metal. The main reason for this is air pollution caused by the burning of fossil fuels. The Taj Mahal has been affected by acid rain.

questions.question: Which of the following statements is/are NOT correct ? I. The property of metals by which they can be beaten into thin sheets is called malleability. II. The property of metal by which it can being drawn into wires is called ductility.
questions.explanation: Neither I nor II .Malleability - The property of metals to be beaten into thin sheets .Examples - Copper, silver. Ductility - The property of metal to be drawn into wires. Examples - Gold, silver and copper. Density and melting point of metals is high.

questions.question: Which of the following liquids can dissolve noble metals such as gold and platinum?
questions.explanation: Aqua regia is a mixture of hydrochloric acid and nitric acid present in the ratio 3:1.

questions.question: Which of the following statements is NOT correct regarding the alkali metals ?

options.a: All the alkali metals are silvery white, soft and light metals.
options.b: The ionization enthalpies of the alkali metals are considerably low and decrease down the group from.
options.c: Group 1 metals are known as alkali metals.
options.d: All the alkali metals have two valence electrons.

questions.explanation: Alkali metals have one electron in their valence shell. Group 1A of the periodic table are the alkali metals: Hydrogen (H, 1), Lithium (Li, 3), Sodium (Na, 11), Potassium (K , 19), Rubidium (Rb, 37), Cesium (Cs, 55), and Francium (Fr , 87). Lithium was discovered in 1817, taking its name from the Greek word for "stone".

questions.question: Choose the most reactive metal from the options given below.
questions.explanation: Sodium. Reactive metals in order: Potassium (Most reactive metal), Sodium, Barium, Calcium, Magnesium, Aluminium, Zinc, Iron, Nickel, Tin, Lead, Hydrogen, Copper, Mercury, Silver, Gold, Platinum (Least Reactive).

questions.question: Which of the following statements is INCORRECT ?

options.a: Metals react with oxygen to form basic oxides.
options.c: Non-metals do not produce any sound

questions.explanation: Physical Properties of Non metals: Poor conductors of electricity and heat, Non-malleable nor ductile, Brittle solids, May be solids, liquids, or gases at room temperature, These are not sonorous, and Transparent.

questions.question: Which of the following metals reacts violently with cold water ?
questions.explanation: Potassium and sodium react violently with cold water, where sodium reacts slightly stronger than Potassium. The reaction is exothermic in nature andin each reaction, hydrogen gas is given off and the metal hydroxide is produced.

questions.question: Identify the INCORRECT pair with respect to the substances and their speci ﬁ c heat capacity (J ) at 𝑘𝑔−1𝐾−1 room temperature and atmospheric pressure.
questions.explanation: Water has a speci ﬁ c heat capacity of 4186 Jkg-1K-1.Speci ﬁ c heat of some substance - Iron/Steel - 450, Copper - 390, Silver - 230, Mercury - 140, Platinum - 130, Hydrogen - 14000, Air - 718, Ice - 2100, Sea Water - 3900 etc.

questions.question: The particles of which metal on heating to the boiling point of 357°C go from liquid state to gas state?
questions.explanation: Mercury (Hg, Atomic Number-80) is also a good conductor of electricity, so it is a useful component of electrical switches. Mercury is also used in dental ﬁllings, paints, soaps, batteries, and ﬂuor escent lighting. It is commonly known as quicksilver and was formerly named hydrargyrum.

questions.question: Which metal sulphate, composed of potassium, aluminium, and sulphate ions in the ratio 1 : 1 : 2, plays a role as a ﬂame retardant, a mordant and an astringent?
questions.explanation: Potash alum (Potassium Aluminium sulphate). The chemical formula of potash alum is K2SO4.Al2(SO4)3.24H2O. It is also commonly referred to as ‘ﬁ tkari.’ Extracted from a mineral called alunite. It is used for the puri ﬁ cation of impure water, stops bleeding, and is mordant for the dyeing industry, leather tanning, ﬁr eproof textiles, and baking powder.

questions.question: Ozone is an allotrope of ______.
questions.explanation: Oxygen. Ozone (O3) is a triatomic allotrope of oxygen. Ozone is a powerful oxidant (far more so than dioxygen) and has many industrial and consumer applications related to oxidation.

questions.question: Which of the following is a property of silicon dioxide?

options.d: It has a high melting point.

questions.explanation: Silicon dioxide (SiO2) has a high melting point. It has melting and boiling points as 1713º C and 2950º C, respectively. The density is about 2.648 g/cm3.

questions.question: Which of the following minerals has kieserite as its ore ?
questions.explanation: Magnesium . Kieserite is a magnesium sulphate mineral. It is used in the production of Epsom salt and as a fertiliser in agriculture.

questions.question: Identify the alloy among the following of which lead is a component.
questions.explanation: Solder is a metal alloy usually made of tin and lead. Alnico - aluminium (Al), nickel (Ni), and cobalt (Co). Constantan - A copper-nickel alloy used in electrical work for its high resistance.

questions.question: Which of the following is one of the metals used in LED semiconductor technology ?
questions.explanation: Gallium is a metallic material that is found as a trace element in coal, bauxite, and other minerals. Other metals such as arsenic, indium, and the rare-earth elements (REEs) cerium, europium, gadolinium, lanthanum, terbium, and yttrium are also used in LED semiconductor technology.

questions.question: Which of the following is used as a substitute of mercury in thermometers?
questions.explanation: Galinstan. An alloy composed of gallium, indium, and tin which melts at −19 °C and is thus liquid at room temperature.

questions.question: The pH value of the curd is:

options.b: lower than the pH value of milk
options.c: higher than the pH value of milk

questions.explanation: lower than the pH value of milk. The pH value of curd is between 4.5 and 5.5, meaning it is more acidic than fresh milk which has a pH of around 6. When milk turns into curd, bacteria called Lactobacillus convert the sugar in milk (lactose) into lactic acid, causing the milk proteins to coagulate and forming curd. The pH levels of some common substances: Baking soda (9), Borax (9.2), Lime water (12.4), Lemon juice (about 2.2), Gastric juice (about 1.2), Pure water (7), Blood (7.4), Milk of magnesia (10), Sodium hydroxide solution (about 14).

questions.question: Which of the following raw materials is NOT used to prepare the baking soda?
questions.explanation: Na 2CO3.The raw materials used to prepare baking soda are: Sodium chloride (NaCl): Also known as common salt, this is the source of sodium ions. Ammonia (NH₃): Reacts with carbon dioxide and water to form ammonium bicarbonate. Carbon dioxide (CO ₂): Reacts with ammonium bicarbonate to precipitate out sodium bicarbonate. Water (H₂O): Used in the reaction. Reaction: NaCl + H2O + CO2+ NH3→ NH 4CI + NaHCO 3.

questions.question: Which of the following is a correct order of basicity ?
questions.explanation: CsOH>KOH>NaOH>LiOH. This order is due to the increasing size of the alkali metal ions, which leads to better solvation and greater basicity. As you move down the group, the basicity increases because the larger alkali metal ions (like Cs⁺) can more easily dissociate and interact with water compared to the smaller ions (like Li⁺).

questions.question: Which polyatomic ionic compound is a white, crystalline powder used in ﬁr e extinguishers and to neutralise acids and bases ?
questions.explanation: Sodium Bicarbonate (NaHCO3)is used as a pH buffering agent, an electrolyte replenisher, systemic alkalizer and in topical cleansing solutions. Sodium Bisulphite (NaHSO3) appears as white crystals or crystalline powder used in food processing, photography.

questions.question: Which of the following is the most acidic ?
questions.explanation: HCOOH (Formic acid). The closer the pH is to 0, the stronger the acid. According to the Arrhenius theory, acids increase the concentration of hydrogen ions (H⁺) in water. Fluoroantimonic acid is recognized as the strongest acid ever discovered.

questions.question: Why does the milkman add a very small amount of baking soda to fresh milk ?

options.a: To reduce the pH of the fresh milk from 6 to slightly more acidic
options.b: To increase the pH of the fresh milk from 6 to slightly alkaline
options.c: To maintain the pH of the fresh milk at 6 for a longer time
options.d: To reduce the pH of the fresh milk from 6 to slightly alkaline

questions.explanation: A milkman adds a small amount of baking soda (NaHCO3) to fresh milk to prevent its acidi ﬁ cation, allowing him to store it for a longer time. This is because milk in an alkaline condition does not curdle easily.

questions.question: Which acid is used as a souring agent added to vinegar, pickled vegetables, and sauces, and as a raw material for seasoning?
questions.explanation: Acetic acid (CH3COOH). It is a colorless, organic compound that is a carboxylic acid.

questions.question: In which year did Johannes Nicolaus Bronsted and Thomas Martin Lowry propose the fundamental concept of acids and bases ?
questions.explanation: 1923. According to Bronsted-Lowry theory, acid is a substance which donates an H+ ion or a proton and forms its conjugate base and the base is a substance which accepts an H+ ion or a proton and forms its conjugate acid.

questions.question: The reaction of an acid and a metal gives:

options.d: carbon dioxide, salt and hydrogen gas

questions.explanation: hydrogen gas and salt. When an acid reacts with a metal, the products are typically a salt and hydrogen gas. For example, when sodium (Na) reacts with hydrochloric acid (HCl), the reaction produces sodium chloride (NaCl) and hydrogen gas (H₂). The balanced chemical equation is: 2 Na (s) + 2 HCl (aq)→2 NaCl (aq) + H 2(g).

questions.question: Select olfactory indicator from the given options.
questions.explanation: Clove oil. An olfactory indicator is a substance that smells different when mixed with an acidic or basic solution. Olfactory indicators are used in laboratories to determine if a solution is acidic or basic, a process called olfactory titration. Other olfactory indicators: Onion, Vanilla.

questions.question: What are bases that are soluble in water called ?
questions.explanation: Alkalis. When a base dissolves in water, it forms hydroxide ions (OH ⁻), which makes the solution basic with a pH greater than 7. Not all bases are soluble, but those that are, like sodium hydroxide (NaOH) and potassium hydroxide (KOH), are called alkalis.

questions.question: What is the correct way to mix acid and water?

options.a: The water must be added to the acid.
options.b: The water must be heated before mixing.
options.c: The acid must be heated before mixing.
options.d: The acid must be slowly added to the water.

questions.explanation: The process of dissolving an acid or a base in water is a highly exothermic one. Care must be taken while mixing concentrated nitric acid or sulphuric acid with water. The acid must always be added slowly to water with constant stirring. Mixing an acid or base with water results in a decrease in the concentration of ions (H 3O+/OH–) per unit volume. Such a process is called dilution and the acid or the base is said to be diluted.

questions.question: Match column A with column B.Column-A Column-B i. Lemon a. Tartaric acid ii. Milk b. Citric acid iii. Vinegar c. Lactic acid iv. Tamarind d. Acetic acid
questions.explanation: i-b,ii-c,iii-d,iv-a.

questions.question: A 100 mL solution having 0.01 moles of NaOH dissolved in it. The pH of the solution is:
questions.explanation: 13. Concentration of OH ions = = = 0.1 M.0.01 𝑚𝑜𝑙𝑒𝑠 100 𝑚𝐿 0.01 𝑚𝑜𝑙𝑒𝑠 0.1 𝐿 Hence, [OH−] = 0.1 M. Now, pOH = −𝑙𝑜𝑔 [OH—] pOH = − (10–1). pOH = 1 10 𝑙𝑜𝑔 𝑙𝑜𝑔 = 1. We know that, pH + pOH = 14 pH = 14 − pOH = 14 – 1 = 13.

questions.question: Which potassium salt is a mineral supplement used to treat or prevent low levels of potassium in the blood ?
questions.explanation: Potassium chloride (KCl). Potassium iodide (KI) :A salt that can be used to protect the thyroid gland from radioactive.Potassium citrate (K3C6H5O7). Potassium nitrate (KNO3).

questions.question: The reaction between an acid and a base is known as_______.
questions.explanation: Neutralisationreaction. When a strong acid reacts with a strong base, it results in a salt which is neutral. Example :HCl + NaOH →NaCl + H2O.Q.70. Which acid is predominantly present in tomatoes? SSC MTS 09/05/2023 (Evening) (a) Carbonic acid (b) Acetic acid (c) Oxalic acid (d) Tartaric acid Sol.70.(c) Oxalic acid (C2H2O4). It is found in leafy greens (such as spinach), vegetables, fruits, cocoa, nuts, and seeds.Acetic Acid (CH3COOH) - Vinegar. Malic acid (C4H6O5) is found in apples and apricots. Formic acid or Methanoic acid (HCOOH) is found in bees, nettle stings, ant stings and insects. Carbonic acid is found in all carbonated beverages.

questions.question: Which among the following is a covalent compound?
questions.explanation: Hydrogen chloride. Covalent bond - Formed by the equal sharing of electrons. Examples: Methane (CH4), Hydrochloric acid (HCl).

questions.question: Which of the following is used as an antacid to neutralise stomach acidity?
questions.explanation: Magnesium Hydroxide {Mg(OH)2}.It is an inorganic compound. It is naturally found as the mineral brucite. It can be used as an antacid.

questions.question: When the litmus solution is neither acidic nor basic, its colour is ______.
questions.explanation: Purple. Litmus solution - It is extracted from lichen. Litmus paper (pH paper) - Made by treating the paper with natural dyes from lichens. The base turns Red litmus to blue, while acid turns blue litmus to red. Some natural Indicators - Red cabbage leaves, turmeric, coloured petals of some ﬂowers (Hydrangea, Petunia and Geranium).

questions.question: Which of the following acids makes the pH of vinegar acidic?
questions.explanation: Acetic acid (CH 3COOH). Vinegar is a liquid that is made by fermenting alcohol. The fermentation process produces acetic acid, which gives vinegar its sour taste and acidic properties. It has a pH of around 2.4.

questions.question: Which of the following statements is/are correct? I. Salts of a strong acid and weak base are acidic with pH value less than 7. II. When electricity is passed through an aqueous solution of sodium chloride (called brine), it decomposes to form sodium oxide.
questions.explanation: Only I. Acids - That gives off hydrogen ions in water and forms salts by combining with certain metals. Strongest acid - Fluoroantimonic acid. Common strong acids: Hydrochloric Acid (HCl), Sulphuric Acid (H 2SO 4), Nitric Acid (HNO 3).Base (pH value > 7) - That can accept hydrogen ions in water and can neutralise an acid. Common strong bases: sodium hydroxide (NaOH), potassium hydroxide (KOH), calcium hydroxide {Ca(OH)2}.

questions.question: Which of the following statements is correct?

options.a: Living organisms can survive a wide range of pH change.
options.b: When pH of rain water is less than 8.2, it is called acid rain.
options.c: Our body works within the pH range of 7.0 to 7.8.
options.d: Tooth decay starts when the pH of the mouth is lower than 1.5.

questions.explanation: The pH (Potential of Hydrogen) range goes from 0 - 14, with 7 being neutral. pH of less than 7 indicates acidity, whereas a pH of greater than 7 indicates a base. Tooth decay begins when the pH of the mouth falls below 5.5.

questions.question: Which of the following substances has a pH value of about 14 ?
questions.explanation: Sodium hydroxide. pH Value : Blood (7.35 to 7.45), Sodium hydroxide (12.3), Milk of magnesia (10.5), Lemon Juice (2.32), Vinegar (2.5), Washing Soda (11). pH Indicator - Phenolphthalein (range pH 8.2 to 10.0; colourless to pink), Bromthymol blue (range pH 6.0 to 7.6; yellow to blue), and litmus (range pH 4.5 to 8.3; red to blue).

questions.question: Muriatic acid is another name of which compound is used in theproduction of chlorides, fertilisers, and dyes, in electroplating, and in the photographic, textile and rubber industries ?
questions.explanation: Hydrochloric acid. It is a component of the gastric acid in the digestive systems of most animal species, including humans. Perchloric acid (HClO4) is also called Hyperchloric acid (HClO 4).

questions.question: What does ‘p’ in pH stand for ?
questions.explanation: Potenz. "pH" is a measure of how acidic/basic water is. It was ﬁrst described by Danish biochemist Soren Peter Lauritz Sorensen in 1909. The p stands for the power or concentration, and the H for the hydrogen ion (H+).

questions.question: Who synthesised acetic acid for theﬁrst time ?
questions.explanation: Kolbe's work was historic because he produced organic compounds from inorganic ones artiﬁ cially.Acetic acid is produced synthetically as well as from bacterial fermentation. In nature it is found in ants and some fruits.

questions.question: What happens when an acid or a base is mixed with water?

options.a: Decrease in the concentration of ions (H2O+/OH–) per unit volume
options.b: Decrease in the concentration of ions (H3O+/OH–) per litre volume
options.c: Increase in the concentration of ions (H3O+/OH–) per unit volume
options.d: Decrease in the concentration of ions (H3O+/OH–) per unit volume

questions.explanation: Acids in water dissociate H+ ions . When an acidic solution is diluted with water, the concentration of H+ions decreases and the pH of the solution increases towards 7. When an alkali is diluted with water, the concentration of OH–ions decreases, and the pH of the alkali fall towards 7.

questions.question: Acidic nature of soil is shown by high concentration of ______ .
questions.explanation: Hydrogen is used in the synthesis of ammonia and the manufacture of nitrogenous fertilisers. The main function of phosphorus is in the formation of bones and teeth. Nitrogen is important to the chemical industry. It is used to make fertilisers, nitric acid, nylon, dyes and explosives.

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT a natural acid-base indicator?
questions.explanation: Thyme leaves is a herb and also has medicinal use. Geranium ﬂowers, Petunia ﬂowers, and Red cabbage act as a pH indicator due to the presence of the water-soluble vacuolar pigment named Anthocyanin.

questions.question: What are the best examples of Phyllosilicates?
questions.explanation: Micas, chlorite, talc, and serpentine . The phyllosilicates, or sheet silicates, are an important group of minerals that includes clay minerals. The basic structure of the phyllosilicates is based on interconnected six member rings of SiO4-4tetrahedra that extend outward in in ﬁ nite sheets.

questions.question: Which of the following is the most widely used method for re ﬁ ning impure metals?
questions.explanation: Electrolytic Reﬁ ning. It is a technique used for the extraction and puriﬁ cation of metals by the process of electrolysis. Metals like copper, nickel, gold, lead, silver, and zinc can be puri ﬁ ed using electrolytic re ﬁ ning.

questions.question: Which is the most common ore of oxidised mercury that occurs in granular crusts or veins associated with volcanic activity and hot springs?
questions.explanation: Cinnabar (HgS) - An ore of Mercury (Hg). Diaspore {AlO(OH)} occurs as platy masses in highly aluminous metamorphic rocks associated with corundum. Siderite , also called chalybite, is iron carbonate (FeCO 3), a widespread mineral that is an ore of iron. Corundum, naturally occurring Aluminium oxide mineral (Al2O3) that is, after diamond, the hardest known natural substance.

questions.question: The process in which metals are extracted from their ores by heating beyond the melting point is called________ .
questions.explanation: Smelting. Roasting is a process of heating a sulphide ore to a high temperature in the presence of air. Calcination - A process of heating some solid material or a substance in a controlled environment. Spinning - The process of converting staple or short lengths of ﬁbr e, such as cotton or rayon, into continuous yarn or thread.

questions.question: Which of the following is a tough, porous and black substance, and almost a pure form of carbon ?
questions.explanation: Coke. It is the purest form of carbon with 98 % carbon. It is a fuel with few impurities and a high carbon content, usually made from coal.

questions.question: Dolomite is an ore of :
questions.explanation: Magnesium is found in minerals such as magnesite, dolomite, brucite, serpentinite, etc. and is mostly recovered from seawater, brines and bitterns. Dolomite formula - MgCO3· CaCO3.

questions.question: ______ is a process of forming a thick oxide layer of aluminium.
questions.explanation: Anodising . Aluminium oxide coat makes it resistant to further corrosion. It is also useful in architectural ﬁnishing.

questions.question: Which of the following ﬁbr es is used to make rayon cloth ?
questions.explanation: Cellulose. Rayon - It is a synthetic ﬁbr e made from wood and related agricultural products.

questions.question: According to a law postulated by ______, the amounts of different substances liberated by the same quantity of electricity passing through the electrolytic solution are proportional to their chemical equivalent weights.
questions.explanation: Michael Faraday. Law of Electrolysis states that the amount of chemical change produced by current at an electrode-electrolyte boundary is proportional to the quantity of electricity used, and the amounts of chemical changes produced by the same quantity of electricity in different substances are proportional to their equivalent weights.

questions.question: With reference to metals and their ores, which of the following pairs is INCORRECT ?
questions.explanation: Mercury is either found as a native metal (rare) or in cinnabar, metacinnabar, corderoite, living stoneite and other minerals. Greenockite is a rare cadmium bearing metal sulphide mineral consisting of cadmium sulphide in crystalline form. Major ores of aluminium are Bauxite, Corundum, Feldspar, Cryolite, Alunite and Kaolin. Smelite is an ore of Cobalt.

questions.question: In acetylene (C2H2), hybridzation of carbon atoms is:
questions.explanation: sp. Acetylene appears as a colorless gas with a faint garlic-like odor. Easily ignited and burned with a sooty ﬂame. In acetylene the carbon atoms undergo sp hybridization, resulting in a linear molecular geometry. This is because the carbon atoms form a triple bond with each other, which requires the sp hybridization. Hybridization is the process of mixing atomic orbitals to create new hybrid orbitals with differentenergies, shapes, and other properties. These hybrid orbitals are suited for electron pairing to form chemical bonds.

questions.question: The IUPAC name of CH3-(CH2)18 -CH3is ________.
questions.explanation: icosane. It is a waxy, hydrophobic hydrocarbon lipid from the alkane class, practically insoluble in water, neutral, and with a high ﬂash point. Used in phase change materials (PCMs) for thermal energy storage and temperature control. The International Union of Pure and Applied Chemistry (IUPAC), which advances chemical sciences, is headquartered in the United States.

questions.question: The property by virtue of which carbon can form a C-C covalent bond is called _______.
questions.explanation: Catenation is the property of carbon that allows it to form long chains, branched structures, or rings through C-C covalent bonds. This unique ability is due to carbon's small size and strong covalent bonding, which enables it to form stable bonds with other carbon atoms. Allotropy - The existence of an element in different physical forms having similar chemical properties. Tetravalency - The ability of an atom to form four covalent bonds with other atoms. Carbon is a tetravalent element. Covalency - The number of chemical bonds that an atom can form with other atoms in a molecule.

questions.question: To which of the following classes of compounds does cyclohexane belong?
questions.explanation: Alicyclic compound. They are organic compounds that are both aliphatic and cyclic. These are the saturated or unsaturated hydrocarbons containing non-aromatic rings of carbon atoms. They have one or more aliphatic side chains attached. Examples: Cyclopropane, Cyclobutane, Cyclopentane, Cyclopentene, Cyclohexane, Cyclohexene, etc.

questions.question: 0.25 g of an organic compound gave 0.13 g of water after complete combustion. The percentage composition of hydrogen is _________.
questions.explanation: 5.78%. To calculate the percentage of hydrogen: Molecular weight of water (H₂O) : 2 (H) + 16 (O) = 18 mol/g. Hydrogen's contribution in water = = .2 181 9 Mass of hydrogen in 0.13 g of water: 0.13 × = 0.0144g.1 9 Percentage of hydrogen in the organic compound: × 100𝑀𝑎𝑠𝑠 𝑜𝑓 𝐻𝑦𝑑𝑟𝑜𝑔𝑒𝑛 𝑀𝑎𝑠𝑠 𝑜𝑓 𝐶𝑜𝑚𝑝𝑜𝑢𝑛𝑑 = × 100 = 5.78%.0.0144 0.

questions.question: How many covalent bonds are present between the constituent atoms in the molecules of Butane and Hexane, respectively?
questions.explanation: 13and19. Structure of Butane (C4H10): It has 4 carbon atoms arranged in a chain, each bonded with single covalent bonds. Each carbon atom is also bonded to hydrogen atoms to satisfy the valency of 4. Covalent bonds in Butane: Carbon-carbon single bonds = 3. Carbon-hydrogen bonds = 10. Total = 3 + 10 = 13 covalent bonds. Structure of Hexane (C6H14): It has 6 carbon atoms in a straight chain, each bonded with single covalent bonds, and bonded to hydrogen atoms to satisfy the valency of 4. Covalent bonds in Hexane: Carbon-carbon single bonds = 5. Carbon-hydrogen bonds = 14. Total = 5 + 14 = 19 covalent bonds.

questions.question: Palladium on barium sulphate (Pd/BaSO4) is also known as:
questions.explanation: theRosenmundcatalyst. The Rosenmund reduction is a hydrogenation process in which an acyl chloride is selectively reduced to an aldehyde. The reaction was named after Karl Wilhelm Rosenmund. The Rosenmund catalyst can be prepared by reduction of palladium(II) chloride solution in the presence of BaSO4. Catalyst used :Hillman reaction (a nucleophilic catalyst, such as a tertiary amine or phosphine), Cannizzaro reaction (ytterbium tri ﬂ ate).

questions.question: When haloalkanes and aryl and vinyl halides react with magnesium metal they yield which reagent ?
questions.explanation: Grignard reagent. The chemical formula for Grignard reagents is R-Mg-X, where R represents an aryl or alkyl group and X represents a halogen (Cl, Br, I). The Tollens reagent is used to test for the presence of aldehydes. Hinsberg Reagent is a chemical compound used in organic chemistry, speci ﬁ cally in the study of amines.

questions.question: Which of the following is a saturated hydrocarbon?
questions.explanation: C3H8. Saturated Hydrocarbons: Contain only single covalent bonds, making them less reactive. Example: Alkanes (C nH2n+2). Unsaturated Hydrocarbons: Contain at least one double or triple carbon-carbon bond, making them more reactive. Examples: Alkenes (C nH2n) and Alkynes (CnH2n-2).

questions.question: An organic reaction used to convert an aryl diazonium salt into an aryl halide using a copper(I) halide catalyst is called:
questions.explanation: Sandmeyer reaction is a type of substitution reaction that is widely used in the production of aryl halides from aryl diazonium salts. The reaction was discovered in 1884 by Swiss chemist Traugott Sandmeyer. Balz–Schiemann reaction is a chemical reaction that converts primary aromatic amines into aryl ﬂuorides. Gattermann reaction is a chemical reaction in which aromatic compounds are formulated by a mixture of hydrogen cyanide (HCN) and hydrogen chloride (HCl) in the presence of a Lewis acid catalyst such as AlCl3.

questions.question: Name the straight chain alkane having chemical formula C 9H20, which is used as a research chemical and in making biodegradable detergents.
questions.explanation: Nonane is a colorless liquid with a smell like gasoline. It's found in gasoline, Stoddard solvent (It is a clear, colorless liquid made from petroleum.) Dodecane (C12H26), a constituent of kerosene oil on heating to 973K in the presence of platinum, palladium or nickel gives a mixture of heptane and pentene.

questions.question: Which of the following reactions leads to the formation of glucose pentaacetate from acetic anhydride ?
questions.explanation: Acetylation of glucose. Acetylation is a chemical reaction in which an acetyl group (CH3CO-) is introduced into a molecule. For glucose, acetylation occurs when glucose reacts with acetic anhydride, producing glucose pentaacetate. The reaction can be represented as: Glucose + 5 Acetic Anhydride →Glucose Pentaacetate + 5 Acetic Acid.

questions.question: What is the IUPAC name of the compound CH3NH2?
questions.explanation: Methanamine. This compound consists of a single carbon atom (from CH3) attached to an amine group (-NH2), so its IUPAC name is derived from methane (one carbon) plus amine.

questions.question: Why is the six membered cyclic structure of glucose called a pyranose structure ?

options.a: Pyran is a non-cyclic organic compound, with one oxygen atom and ﬁv e carbon atoms in the ring.
options.b: Furan is a ﬁv e membered cyclic compound, with one oxygen and four carbon atoms.
options.c: Pyran is a cyclic organic compound, with one oxygen atom and ﬁv e carbon atoms in the ring.
options.d: Furan is a ﬁv e membered non-cyclic compound, with one oxygen and four carbon atoms.

questions.explanation: The six membered cyclic structure of glucose is called pyranose structure in analogy with pyran. Pyran is a cyclic organic compound with one oxygen atom and ﬁv e carbon atoms in the ring. The cyclic structure of glucose is more correctly represented by the Haworth structure.

questions.question: What is the name of the aromatic compound in the given ﬁgur e ?
questions.explanation: Naphthalene is used in mothballs, dye production, plastics, insecticides, fungicides, and pharmaceuticals. Aromatic hydrocarbons, or arenes, are compounds with a pleasant odor, often containing a benzene ring.

questions.question: Which of the following organic compounds is a benzenoid?
questions.explanation: Aniline. Aromatic compounds are special types of compounds. These include benzene and other related ring compounds (benzenoid). Benzenoid aromatic compounds: Benzene, Naphthalene. Like alicyclic compounds, aromatic compounds may also have hetero atoms in the ring. Such compounds are called heterocyclic aromatic compounds. Example -Furan, Thiophene, Pyridine.

questions.question: Identify a substance that is NOT an allotrope of carbon.
questions.explanation: Phosphorus. Allotropes are different forms of a chemical element in the same physical state, arising from various atomic bonding arrangements. Fullerene, discovered by Richard Smalley in 1985, consists of a large spheroidal molecule made up of sixty or more atoms, with buckminsterfullerene being theﬁrst known example.

questions.question: Which of the following compounds is an Alicyclic compound?
questions.explanation: Cyclopropane. Alicyclic (aliphatic cyclic) compounds contain carbon atoms joined in the form of a ring(homocyclic). Sometimes atoms other than carbon are also present in the ring (heterocyclic). Some examples of this type of compounds are: Cyclohexane, Cyclohexene, Tetrahydrofuran.

questions.question: Which of the following is an open chain organic compound?
questions.explanation: Acetaldehyde (CH 3CHO) : IUPAC name - Ethanal. Acetaldehyde is used primarily as a starting material in the manufacture of acetic acid, ethyl acetate, vinyl acetate, polymers and drugs. Benzene - C 6H6. Toluene - C6H5CH 3.

questions.question: Match Column-A with Column-B. Column-A Column-B a. Alkanes i. Ethane b. Alkenes ii. Butyne c. Alkynes iii. Propene d. Aldehyde iv. Methanal
questions.explanation: a-i,b-iii,c-ii,d-iv.

questions.question: Which is a colourless, odourless gas of the alkane series of hydrocarbons with a chemical formula of C3H8?
questions.explanation: Propane. Its main uses include home and water heating, cooking and refrigerating food, clothes drying, and powering farm and industrial equipment. The chemical formula for ethane is C2H6, for butane is C4H10, and for pentane is C5H12.

questions.question: Which unsaturated aliphatic hydrocarbon composed of 20 carbon atoms is used to make candles and para ﬃ n wax with solar energy storage capacity?
questions.explanation: Eicosane (C20H42) - It is a very hydrophobic molecule, practically insoluble in water, and relatively neutral. It is considered to be a hydrocarbon lipid molecule.

questions.question: Which synthetic aromatic organic compound inhibits the chemical breakdown of food that occurs in the presence of oxygen, commonly used infoods such as crackers, microwave popcorn, butter and chicken nuggets?
questions.explanation: Tertiary butyl hydroquinone {TBHQ (C10H14O2)} - Food preservative: In foods, TBHQ is used as a preservative for unsaturated vegetable oils and many edible animal fats.

questions.question: Tribromomethane is a synonym for which brominated organic solvent ?
questions.explanation: Bromoform is a colorless liquid with a sweet odor. Uses- including ﬁr e extinguishers, fumigants, and solvents.

questions.question: Methyl ethyl ketone is also known as:
questions.explanation: 2-butanone. It is a colourless liquid with a sharp, sweet odour. It is a common solvent and is used in a variety of industrial and commercial applications.

questions.question: Which of the following does NOT belong to the family of organic compounds?
questions.explanation: Ammonia (NH3)is an inorganic compound of nitrogen and Hydrogen.

questions.question: Which compound structure includes a saturated short-chain fatty acid with 4-carbon molecules, commonly found in esteri ﬁ ed form in animal fats and plant oils ?
questions.explanation: Butyric acid (C4H8O2). Propionic Acid (C3H6O2) - A colourless liquid with a sharp rancid odour. It is a short-chain saturated fatty acid comprising ethane attached to the carbon of a carboxy group. Succinic Acid (C4H6O4) - An alpha, omega-dicarboxylic acid resulting from the formal oxidation of each of the terminal methyl groups of butane to the corresponding carboxy group.

questions.question: What is the IUPAC name of the organic compound depicted in the ﬁgur e?
questions.explanation: 1-Methyl-3-Propylcyclohexan e: Its molecular formula is C10H20.

questions.question: Which of the following is a primary arylamine in which an amino functional group is substituted for one of the benzene hydrogens?
questions.explanation: Aniline (C 6H5NH2).Pyridine (C5H5N) is a colourless liquid with an unpleasant smell. It is used to make medicines, vitamins, food ﬂa vourings, and paints. Toluidine (C 7H9N) is used in dyes, and in organic chemical manufacturing.

questions.question: Which of the following is a white to yellowish solid with a weak aromatic odour puri ﬁ ed by the process of sublimation ?
questions.explanation: Anthracene (C14H10).It is a colourless crystalline aromatic hydrocarbon, and a three-fused benzene ring solid polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbon (PAH). It is a component of coal tar. Anthracene is used in the production of the red dye alizarin and other dyes.

questions.question: What is the systematic name of a colourless gas with a faint, ethereal odour called acetylene, widely used for welding ?
questions.explanation: Ethyne (Formula - C2H2, IUPAC Name - Acetylene): It is a hydrocarbon that is commonly used in various industrial applications. It is a colourless gas with a distinct odour and is highly ﬂammable. Ethanoic anhydride (C4H6O3). Azoethane (C4H10N2). Ethyl acetate (C 4H8O2).

questions.question: Which potassium acid salt is obtained as a by-product of alcoholmanufacture during the fermentation process?
questions.explanation: Potassium bitartrate (KC 4H5O6):Common Name - Cream of tartar. Uses - Additive, Stabilizer, pH control agent.

questions.question: Lactitol is derived through the hydrogenation of:
questions.explanation: Lactose (Milk sugar). It is a disaccharide which is made by the condensation of glucose and galactose. Examples : Butter, Cheese, Cream, Dried milk, Milk solids, Powdered milk, and Whey.

questions.question: In which dialdehyde are two formyl groups attached to adjacent carbon centres on a benzene ring and from ﬂuor escent conjugation products with primary amines?
questions.explanation: Phthalaldehyde {C6H4(CHO) 2} :Uses - for the detection of biogenic amines, peptides, proteins in nanogram quantities in body ﬂuids.

questions.question: Heating ethanol with excess concentrated sulphuric acid produces:
questions.explanation: Ethene (C2H4).CH3CH2OH (aq) + H2SO4(conc.) →C2H4+ H2O. In this reaction Concentrated sulphuric acid acts as a dehydrating agent.

questions.question: Which of the following is a valid bond in Alkenes that connects carbon atoms?
questions.explanation: DoubleBond.Alkene (CnH2n). Example - Ethene (C2H4), Propene (C3H6), Butene (C4H8). Alkyne (CnH2n-2)- Hydrocarbon consists of carbon bound to a carbon with a triple bond, and each carbon is then attached to zero or one hydrogen atom. Example - Ethyne (C 2H2), Propyne (C 3H4).Alkanes (CnH2n+2) - Contains strong carbon-carbon singlebonds and strong carbon-hydrogen bonds. Example -Methane (CH4), Ethane (C2H6) .

questions.question: Which of the following compounds having the molecular formula C2H is derived from the hydride of acetylene ?
questions.explanation: Ethynyl. An organic radical and a terminal acetylenic compound. Uses: Fuel, Industrial applications, Medical applications.

questions.question: Trichloromethane is better known as:
questions.explanation: Chloroform (CHCl3)-It is used as an ideal anaesthetic. It is a colourless, sweet-smelling dense liquid. Other names - Formyl Trichloride, TriChloroform.

questions.question: What is the product formed when CH3CH2OH reacts with O2?
questions.explanation: CO2+ H2O + heat and light.

questions.question: ________ is a naturally occurring organic compound with the formula (C6H5)2CO .
questions.explanation: Benzophenone. Benzophenone is used as an ultraviolet curing agent, ﬂa vour ingredient, fragrance enhancer and perfume ﬁxativ e, and as an additive for plastics, coatings and adhesive formulations.

questions.question: Which element was arbitrarily assigned a value of 4.0 in the ‘Halogens’ section in 1922 by Linus Pauling, an American scientist ?
questions.explanation: Fluorine - It is an univalent poisonous gaseous halogen; Pale yellow-green; Most chemically reactive and electronegative of all the elements.

questions.question: 1,3-Dimethylbenzene also known a:
questions.explanation: m-Xylene: An isomer of dimethylbenzene. The three isomers of dimethylbenzene are commonly named ortho-xylene, meta-xylene, and para -xylene.

questions.question: A class of organic compounds that contain an oxygen between two alkyl groups is called:
questions.explanation: Ether. They have the formula R-O-R', with R's being the alkyl groups. These compounds are used in dye, perfumes, oils, waxes and industrial use.

questions.question: Which of the following organic compounds is synonymous with ole ﬁ ant gas which is used to make anaesthetics, refrigerants and other chemicals?
questions.explanation: Ethylene (C2H4): A colourless ﬂammable gas with a faint ‘sweet and musky’ odour when pure, Simplest form of organic compounds and used in fruit ripening.

questions.question: Dry ice, ammonium chloride, naphthalene balls and camphor, all these compounds are an example of:
questions.explanation: Sublimable substances: Sublimation is the process by which a solid directly transforms into a gas without passing through the liquid state.

questions.question: Pectin, which is responsible for the ﬁrmness and softness of fruits, is mainly composed of which acid unit?
questions.explanation: Galacturonic acid (C6H10O7)- An acidifying agent in foods and the monomer of pectin molecules.

questions.question: What is the colour of the ﬂame when unsaturated hydrocarbons burn?
questions.explanation: Yellow. In the unsaturated hydrocarbons, the percentagecomposition of carbon is high and atmospheric oxygen is not enough to burn all the carbon present. Hence, unburnt carbon particles are present in theﬂame giving it a sooty feel. Saturated hydrocarbons burn with blueﬂame . It contains less carbon content, so there is a complete combustion of these compounds.

questions.question: Butan - 2 - ol is a:
questions.explanation: Secondary alcohol : Where the carbon atom of the hydroxyl group is attached to two alkyl groups on either side. Examples - Propan-2-ol, Butan-2-ol, Pentan-2-ol. Primary alcohols: The carbon atom of the hydroxyl group (-OH) is bonded to just one alkyl group. Examples - Methanol (CH 3OH), Propanol (C3H7OH), Ethanol (C2H5OH).

questions.question: Choose the correct set of the names for the organic compounds in the given ﬁgur e.

options.a: a: Furan, b: Toluene, c: Pyridine
options.b: a: Furan, b: Pyridine, c: Thiophene
options.c: a: Furan, b: Thiophene, c: Aniline
options.d: a: Anisole, b: Thiophene, c: Pyridine

questions.explanation: a:Furan,b:Pyridine,c:Thiophene.

questions.question: What is the strength of a hydrogen bond determined by ?

options.a: Interaction between the lone-pair electrons of the electronegative atom of one molecule and the hydrogen atom of another molecule
options.b: Interaction between the lone-pair electrons of the electropositive atom of one molecule and the hydrogen atom of another molecule
options.c: Interaction between the lone-pair electrons of the electronegative atom of one molecule and the oxygen atom of another molecule
options.d: Interaction between the lone-pair electrons of the polar molecule and the hydrogen atom of another molecule

questions.explanation: Hydrogen bonding is a special type of dipole-dipole attraction between molecules.

questions.question: Which among the following elements is used in moisturising creamsand soaps because of its hygroscopic properties?
questions.explanation: Glycerol (C3H8O3) - A colourless, odourless, sweet-tasting, viscous liquid that is non-toxic. IUPAC name - Propane -1, 2, 3-triol.

questions.question: Identify a class of compounds that has a functional group -OH.
questions.explanation: Alcohol. Functional Group, Formula, Su ﬃ x and Example : (Alcohol, R-OH, -ol, Methanol), (Ketone, R-(CO)-R’, -one, Butanone), (Aldehyde, R-CHO, -al, Ethanal), (Acyl Halide, R-(CO)-X, -oyl halide, Ethanoyl Chloride), Carboxylate, R-COO–, -oate, Sodium Ethanoate), (Carboxylic Acid, R-COOH, -oic acid, Ethanoic Acid), (Ester, R-(CO)-O-R’, Alkyl alkanoate, Ethyl Butanoate), (Ether, R-O-R’, Alkyl ether, Diethyl Ether).

questions.question: In organic chemistry, which of the following is an empirical rule used to predict the regioselectivity of electrophilic addition reactions of alkanes and alkynes?
questions.explanation: Markovnikov’srule (Vladimir Markovnikov). Bredt's rule states that a double bond cannot be placed at the bridgehead of a bridged ring system unless the rings are large enough. Baldwin's rule (Jack Baldwin) states a series of guidelines outlining the relative favorabilities of ring closure reactions in alicyclic compounds.

questions.question: Name an alkylbenzene widely used as a chemical intermediate in the production of phenol.
questions.explanation: Cumene (isopropylbenzene) is a constituent of crude oil and re ﬁ ned fuels. Uses: manufactures other chemicals (phenol, acetone, etc.), thinner in paints, a component of high-octane motor fuels, in manufacturing of rubber, iron, steel, and pulp and paper.

questions.question: Which of the following is a strong reducing agent used to reduce aldehydes, ketones, esters, carboxylic acid chlorides, carboxylic acids and even carboxylate salts to alcohols?
questions.explanation: Lithium aluminium hydride (LiAlH 4) is a strong, unselective reducing agent for polar double bonds. Strong reducing agent : Sodium Borohydride (NaBH 4), Titanium hydride (TiH 2), Calcium hydride (CaH 2), Bismuth hydride (BiH3).

questions.question: Identify the correct statement with respect to unsaturated hydrocarbons.

options.a: Compounds of carbon having a single bond between their carbon atoms are called unsaturated compounds.
options.b: Compounds of carbon having double bonds or triple bonds between their carbon atoms are called unsaturated compounds.
options.c: Compounds of carbon having single bonds between their oxygen atoms are called unsaturated compounds.
options.d: Compounds of carbon having double or triple bonds between their hydrogen atoms are called unsaturated compounds.

questions.explanation: Unsaturated hydrocarbons are organic compounds that are entirely made up of carbon and hydrogen atoms and consist of a double or a triple bond between two adjacent carbon atoms.

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT an allotrope of carbon?
questions.explanation: Trisulfur . S3is an allotrope of sulphur.

questions.question: Compounds with exactly two double carbon – carbon bonds are known as ______.
questions.explanation: Dienes is a covalent compound that contains two double bonds.

questions.question: Propane and butane are the main components of which of the following gases?
questions.explanation: LPG. Propane (C 3H8) and butane (C 4H10). Ethyl Mercaptan is added to the gas to make it smell like rotten eggs. Lique ﬁ ed natural gas (LNG) and Compressed natural gas (CNG) mainly composed of methane (CH 4). Biogas is a combination of two-thirds of methane (CH 4) and the rest is mostly carbon dioxide (CO 2).

questions.question: Isopentane, also called ________, is a branched-chain saturated hydrocarbon with the chemical formula . 𝐶5𝐻12
questions.explanation: 2-methylbutane. 2, 3 - Dimethylbutane is an isomer of hexane. Isobutane is an alkane that is propane substituted by a methyl group at position two.Butadiene is the raw material for many elastomers, ABS (acrylonitrile butadiene styrene polymer) and in low quantities for nylon and few others.

questions.question: Find the correct chemical formula of nitromethane.
questions.explanation: CH 3NO2.Nitromethane is used to make industrial antimicrobials and pharmaceuticals, and is also used as a soil fumigant and as a fuel in race car engines.

questions.question: Identify the method that is NOT used to purify organic compounds.
questions.explanation: Sedimentation is the process in which particles separate from a liquid because of gravity.

questions.question: Which group was given the name ‘para ﬃ n’ earlier?
questions.explanation: Alkanes are a series of compounds that contain carbon and hydrogen atoms with single covalent bonds.

questions.question: Which chemical compound, with the chemical formula (CH3CH2Cl), is used as a blowing agent in foamed plastics?
questions.explanation: Chloroethane (CH3CH2Cl). Chloromethane (CH3Cl),1- Chloropropane (C3H7Cl), and 3- Chlorohexane (C6H13Cl).

questions.question: Which of the following is an organic compound with the formula C6H4Cl2that is used as a fumigant insecticide to control cloth moths?
questions.explanation: Paradichlorobenzene (C6H4Cl2) is used as a fumigant insecticide to control cloth moths. Ethylbenzene (C6H5CH2CH3) is to manufacture styrene, a compound used to make plastics.

questions.question: Identify the INCORRECT statement regarding the halogens group in the periodic table.

options.a: They have the largest atomic size in their period.
options.c: They form diatomic molecules in their elemental states.
options.d: They are located on the left of the noble gases on the periodic table.

questions.explanation: Halogens, located in Group 17, are situated toward the right of their period, giving them smaller atomic sizes compared to elements on the left. They are reactive non-metals that form diatomic molecules (e.g., Cl2, F2) and are found to the left of the noble gases in the periodic table. The largest atomic size in a period is typically observed in the alkali metals (Group 1), not in the halogens.

questions.question: Which property of an element is inversely related to its ionisation energy?
questions.explanation: Atomic radius. Ionization energy is the energy needed to remove an electron from an atom. As the atomic radius increases, the outer electrons are farther from the nucleus, reducing the attraction between them and the nucleus. This makes it easier to remove an electron, resulting in lower ionization energy. Electronegativity is the ability of an atom to attract shared electrons. Atomic mass is the sum of protons and neutrons, with minor contributions from electrons. Electron a ﬃ nity measures the attraction between an incoming electron and the nucleus, with stronger attraction releasing more energy.

questions.question: According to Newland’s Law of Octaves, every eighth element has properties similar to those of the ﬁrst element. Which of the following elements has properties similar to those of N ?
questions.explanation: P. Newland's Law of Octaves states that when chemical elements are arranged in order of increasing atomic weight, elements with similar properties occur every eight elements. Nitrogen (N) is in the 7th position in the periodic table. To ﬁnd the element with similar properties, we need to add 8 to 7, which gives us 15. The element in the 15th position is Phosphorus (P).

questions.question: Moseley observed that the plot of against atomic number (Z) gave a𝑣 straight line. What does v indicate here ?
questions.explanation: FrequencyofX-raysemitted. Henry Moseley's 1913 experiment involved studying the X-ray spectra of various elements and led to the discovery of atomic numbers. He observed that the frequency (ν) of the X-rays emitted by an element was directly proportional to the square of its atomic number Z.

questions.question: The element with atomic number 59 lies in which block of the Periodic Table?
questions.explanation: Thef-block elements consist of the lanthanoids (atomic numbers 57–71) and actinoids (atomic numbers 89–103). The lanthanoids include Lanthanum (57), Cerium (58), Praseodymium (59), Neodymium (60), and others up to Lutetium (71). The actinoids include Actinium (89), Thorium (90), Uranium (92), Neptunium (93), and others up to Lawrencium (103). These elements are known for their unique properties and are primarily found in the rare-earth group.

questions.question: In which musical note did Newland put the metals Co and Ni with halogens?
questions.explanation: Do. The Newland table was created by John Newlands in 1866 based on his Law of Octaves. He observed that every eighth element exhibited properties similar to the ﬁrst, drawing an analogy to the octaves in music.

questions.question: 'Au' is the symbol for which of the following elements?
questions.explanation: Gold. It is derived from the Latin word "Aurum." Aluminium : Symbol is Al (from Latin "Alumen"). Silver: Symbol is Ag (from Latin "Argentum"). Argon: Symbol is Ar.

questions.question: To which group do the alkaline earth metals such as radium, barium and strontium belong?
questions.explanation: Group 2A. Alkaline earth metals belong to Group 2A (or Group II) of the periodic table, including : Radium (Ra), Barium (Ba), Strontium (Sr), Calcium (Ca), Magnesium (Mg), Beryllium (Be). Group 3A (Boron Group) : This group includes elements like boron (B), aluminum (Al), and gallium (Ga). Group 5A (Nitrogen Group) : This group includes elements like nitrogen (N), phosphorus (P), and arsenic (As).

questions.question: Which of the following elements is a metalloid ?
questions.explanation: Silicon. Metalloids are elements that exhibit properties of both metals and non-metals. The Modern Periodic Table features a zig-zag line separating metals from non-metals. Seven elements along this borderline exhibit intermediate properties and are classi ﬁ ed as metalloids or semi-metals : Boron (B), Germanium (Ge), Arsenic (As), Antimony (Sb), Tellurium (Te), Polonium (Po).

questions.question: Transition elements are the elements that are found in Groups 3-12 of the modern periodic table, that constitute the _____
questions.explanation: d-block. Transition metalsare de ﬁ ned as metals that have an incomplete d subshell in either their neutral atom or in their ions. p-block elements are located in groups 13–18 of the periodic table. S-block elements are in groups 1 and 2 of the periodic table. The f-block consists of elements in which 4 f and 5 f orbitals are progressively ﬁlled. They are placed in a separate panel at the bottom of the periodic table. Q.169 . Which of the following is NOT a halogen gas? SSC CGL 17/09/2024 (2nd Shift) (a) F (b) He (c) Cl (d) Br Sol.169.(b) Helium (He) is a chemical element with atomic number 2. It is a colorless, odorless, tasteless, non-toxic, inert gas and the ﬁrst in the Noble gas group in the periodic table.

questions.question: In the context of periodicity, a unit called picometre is used to measure the __________.
questions.explanation: atomicradius(Atomic Radii). It is the total distance from the nucleus of an atom to the outermost orbital of its electron. In chemistry, the molar mass of a chemical compound is de ﬁ ned as the ratio between the mass and the amount of substance of any sample of the compound. The atomic number density is the number of atoms of a given type per unit volume (V, cm3) of the material.

questions.question: Identify a monoatomic molecule.
questions.explanation: Helium (He) is a noble gas (Group 18 in the periodic table). Molecules: These are made up of one or more atoms and can be classi ﬁ ed into three types: Monatomic, Diatomic and Triatomic. Monatomic molecules : Contain a single atom without covalent bonding, such as noble gases like Helium (He), Neon (Ne), and Argon (Ar). Diatomic molecule : Contains two atoms bonded together, for example hydrogen and oxygen. Triatomic molecules : These are made up of three atoms, which may be the same or different elements, such as ozone (O 3).

questions.question: As per Mendeleev’s prediction, atomic mass of eka-aluminium was :
questions.explanation: 68. Mendeleev left gaps for aluminum and silicon in his periodic table and referred to them as Eka-Aluminum and Eka-Silicon. Mendeleev’s Predictions for the Elements Eka-aluminium (Gallium) and Eka-silicon (Germanium): He predicted the atomic weight of Eka-Aluminum to be 68, while the discovered atomic weight of gallium is 69.72. He also predicted the atomic weight of Eka-Silicon to be 72, and the found atomic weight of germanium is 72.6.

questions.question: In Newlands’ Octaves, the properties of lithium and ________ were found to be the same.
questions.explanation: sodium. In 1865, the English chemist J.A.R. Newlands proposed the Law of Octaves. It states that when chemical elements are arranged by increasing atomic mass, elements with similar physical and chemical properties appear after every interval of seven. Examples include Lithium (Li) and Sodium (Na), as well as Beryllium (Be) and Magnesium (Mg). Limitations : Only applicable up to calcium, assumed only 56 elements existed in nature, and became irrelevant after the discovery of the Noble gases.

questions.question: According to Mendeleev's Periodic Table, which elements’ properties matched up remarkably well with eka-silicon?
questions.explanation: Germanium. Russian chemist Dmitri Mendeleev predicted the existence of several undiscovered elements by leaving gaps in his periodic table and naming them: eka-boron - Later named scandium (Sc); eka-aluminium - Later named gallium (Ga); eka-silicon - Later named germanium (Ge); eka-manganese - Later named technetium (Tc). Mendeleev believed that the properties of elements are a periodic function of their atomic weights.

questions.question: Which of the following ﬁgur es represents Mendeleev's Periodic Table that was published in a German journal in 1872 ?
questions.explanation: c. Mendeleev published the periodic table in 1869 which displayed 63 elements. His Periodic Table contains vertical columns called ‘groups’ and horizontal rows called ‘periods’.

questions.question: Identify the number of electrons found in the outermost shell of halogen.
questions.explanation: Seven. Group 17 of the Periodic Table consists of the following elements : Fluorine (F), Chlorine (Cl), Bromine (Br), Iodine (I), Astatine (At). These elements are extremely reactive. The common oxidation state of these elements is -1. However, the highest oxidation state can be +7. They form oxides, hydrogen halides, interhalogen compounds, and oxoacids.

questions.question: Which of the following depicts the Modern Periodic Table?
questions.explanation: d. The periodic table is an arrangement of chemical elements into rows ("periods") and columns ("groups"), showcasing periodic trends in their properties. It re ﬂ ects the periodic law, which states that elements, ordered by atomic number, show recurring properties. The table is divided into four blocks, with elements in the same group exhibiting similar characteristics.

questions.question: The tendency of an atom or a functional group to attract a shared pair of electrons toward itself, is known as:
questions.explanation: Electronegativity is a chemical property that measures an atom's ability to attract shared electrons in a molecule. The electronegativity of an atom is in ﬂ uenced by its atomic number and the distance of its valence electrons from the positively charged nucleus.

questions.question: According to Dalton, which of thefollowing represents the Phosphorus element ?
questions.explanation: c

questions.question: Which of the following scientists grouped the elements into triads?
questions.explanation: JohannWolfgangDobereiner developed the concept of Dobereiner's Triads in 1817. He observed that certain groups of three elements (triads) had similar chemical properties, and the atomic mass of the middle element was roughly the average of the other two. This was an early attempt to classify elements based on their properties.

questions.question: Which metalloid in the carbon group is chemically similar to its group neighbours tin and silicon?
questions.explanation: Germanium (Ge) is a metalloid in the carbon group (Group 14) of the periodic table, and it is chemically similar to its group neighbors tin (Sn) and silicon (Si). This similarity arises because all three elements share similar electron conﬁ gurations and chemical properties, such as forming covalent bonds and having semiconductor characteristics.

questions.question: Technetium, the ﬁrst artiﬁ cially produced element used in many medical diagnostic imaging scans, is found in which group of the periodic table?
questions.explanation: Group 7. Technetium is a chemical element with atomic number 43, represented by the symbol (Tc). This silvery-gray radioactive metal resembles platinum and is typically found as a gray powder. Technetium dissolves in aqua regia, nitric acid, and concentrated sulfuric acid, but is insoluble in hydrochloric acid. Discovered by Carlo Perrier and Emilio Segre in 1937.

questions.question: Which arti ﬁ cial element has been provisionally named seaborgium by American researchers in honour of Nobel Laureate Glenn T Seaborg?
questions.explanation: Element 106. Seaborgium is a highly radioactive element, with its most stable isotope possessing a half-life of only a few minutes. Its discovery was ﬁrst reported in 1974 by a team of scientists at the Lawrence Berkeley National Laboratory in California. Notable elements include Element 103 - Lawrencium, Element 90 - Thorium, and Element 97 - Berkelium.

questions.question: The likelihood of a neutral atom gaining an electron is known as:
questions.explanation: Electron a ﬃ nity. It refers to the energy change when an electron is added to a neutral gaseous atom, forming a negative ion. Electropositivity, mainly seen in alkali and alkaline earth metals, is an atom's tendency to donate electrons and form positive cations.

questions.question: The behaviour of lithium is similar to that of magnesium. This sort of similarity is commonly referred to as :
questions.explanation: Diagonal relationship. Magnesium and Lithium are almost of the same sizes and electronegativity values are nearly the same because both are found together in nature. A Diagonal Relationship is said to exist between certain pairs of diagonally adjacent elements in the second and third periods of the periodic table. These pairs (Li & Mg, Be & Al, B & Si, etc.) exhibit similar properties.

questions.question: What are the elements in group zero commonly known as ?
questions.explanation: Inertgases: These gasesare called so because they are chemically inert i.e. they do not readily undergo chemical reactions easily. Presence - 18th group. Elements - Helium [He - 2], Neon [Ne - 10], Argon [Ar - 18], Krypton [Kr - 36], Xenon [Xe - 54], Radon [Rn - 86].

questions.question: Which of the following options are all transition metals?
questions.explanation: Cu (copper), Fe (Iron), Ni (nickel), Ti (titanium). Transition elements : Those elements which have partially ﬁlled d-orbitals. The names transition metals and inner transition metals are often used to refer to the elements of d-and f-blocks respectively. Some Transition metals - Scandium (Sc), vanadium (V), chromium (Cr), manganese (Mn), cobalt (Co), zinc (Zn).

questions.question: Which German chemist was the ﬁrst to show a graphical representation of the periodicity of an atomic volume plotted against atomic weight ?
questions.explanation: Lothar Meyer. William Ramsay - British physical chemist who discovered four gases (neon, argon, krypton, xenon) and showed that they (with helium and radon) formed an entire family of new elements, the noble gases. Award: Nobel Prize (1904). Glenn T Seaborg: His work on isolating and identifying transuranium elements (those heavier than uranium).

questions.question: Identify whether the given statements about p-block elements are correct or incorrect. Statement A: In p-block elements, the last electron enters the outermost p orbital. Statement B: The non-metals and metalloids exist only in the p-block of the periodic table.

options.a: Both Statements A and B are correct
options.d: Both Statements A and B are incorrect

questions.explanation: There are six groups of p–block elements in the periodic table numbering from 13 to 18. Boron, carbon, nitrogen, oxygen, ﬂuorine and helium head the groups. Their valence shell electronic con ﬁ guration is ns2np1-6(except for He). The maximum oxidation state shown by a p-block element is equal to the total number of valence electrons. In the P block of periodic table the non-metallic character of elements decreases down the group. In fact the heaviest element in each p-block group is the most metallic in nature.

questions.question: Which of the following elements is a member of the actinide series?
questions.explanation: Thorium. The 15 elements that are part of the Actinides series are: Actinium (Ac), Thorium (Th), Protactinium (Pa), Uranium (U), Neptunium (Np), Plutonium (Pu), Americium (Am), Curium (Cm), Berkelium (Bk), Californium (Cf), Einsteinium (Es), Fermium (Fm), Mendelevium (Md), Nobelium (No), and Lawrencium (Lr).

questions.question: Which chemical element of Group 18 of the periodic table is produced by the natural radioactive decay of uranium in soils and rocks ?
