questions.explanation: Radon (Rn, 86) .It is a radioactive element. It is used in some hospitals to treat tumours by sealing the gas in minute tubes.

questions.question: Which radioactive element with atomic number 43 in the modern periodic table is unstable, and the half-lives of all its isotopes are relatively short, from 4.2 million years to 5.0 s ?
questions.explanation: Technetium. The half-life (t1/2) is the time in which the concentration of a reaction or radioactive substances is reduced to one-half of its initial concentration. t1/2= 0.693/λ. Here λ is the disintegration constant. Other elements and their atomic number: Darmstadtium (Ds) -110, Nihonium (Nh) - 113, Nobelium (No) - 102, Einsteinium (Es) - 99, Fermium (Fm) - 100, Plutonium (Pm) - 61.

questions.question: Which d-block element in the periodic table is represented by the Greek symbol 'alpha' and the metallic 'rays’ ?
questions.explanation: Actinium. It is a silvery radioactive metallic element that glows in the dark due to its intense radioactivity with a blue light. It was discovered in 1899 by André-Louis Debierne. Groups 3 to 12 elements are called d-block or transition elements.

questions.question: Which is the soft, malleable and silvery-yellow metal with atomic number 59 in the lanthanide series ?
questions.explanation: Praseodymium (Pr) - It can be found in houses in equipment such as colour televisions, ﬂuor escent lamps, energy-saving lamps and glasses. It is solid at room temperature.

questions.question: In which group of the Periodic Table will you put the elements with electronic con ﬁ guration [He] ? 2𝑠22𝑝6
questions.explanation: 18. Electronic con ﬁ guration of some elements : Neon (Ne, Atomic number - 10) - [He], 2s22p6(the last orbit is completely ﬁlled). Lithium (Li, Atomic number - 3) - [He], 2s1(last orbit is not completely ﬁlled). Sodium (Na, Atomic number - 11) - 1s2, 2s22p6, 3s1(or) [Ne] 3s1.

questions.question: What is the name of the 87th element on the periodic table that has no known biological role because it has a half-life of only 22 minutes ?
questions.explanation: Francium (Fr): It is in liquid form at room temperature. Second-most electropositive element (after cesium).

questions.question: What is the atomic number of Bohrium which is named after physicist Niels Bohr, one of the founders of quantum theory ?
questions.explanation: 107. Symbol - Bh .The namesake of Bohrium, Niels Bohr, was awarded the Nobel Prize in 1922 for his work on the structure of atoms.

questions.question: Which element of group 13 has the atomic number 113 and its electronic conﬁ guration is [Rn] 5f146d107s27p1?
questions.explanation: Nihonium (Nh)-It is an extremely radioactive synthetic chemical element with a stable isotope, atomic mass - 286 u, has a half-life of 10 seconds and is a transactinide element in the p-block.

questions.question: Identify the element one that does NOT belong to Group 1 of the Modern Periodic Table.
questions.explanation: Hydrogen (H). Alkali metals - They form hydroxides on reaction with water which are strongly alkaline in nature. Physical Properties of Alkali metals - Silvery white, soft, light, malleability, high thermal and electrical conductivity.

questions.question: Identify the last element from the ﬁfth period.
questions.explanation: Xenon. Period - A horizontal row of the periodic table. Total Period - 7 periods, with each one beginning at the far left. Group - A column of elements in the periodic table of the chemical elements. Total Groups - 18.

questions.question: Identify the correct statement about Newlands' law of octaves.

options.a: He started with the element having the highest atomic mass (hydrogen) and ended at thorium which was the 56thelement.
options.b: He started with the element having the lowest atomic mass (hydrogen) and ended at sodium.
options.c: He started with the element having the lowest atomic mass (hydrogen) and ended at aluminium.
options.d: He started with the element having the lowest atomic mass (hydrogen) and ended at thorium which was the 56th element.

questions.explanation: Newlands' law of octaves - when elements are arranged in increasing order of their atomic masses, the properties of the eighth element are a repetition of the properties of the ﬁrst element. It was found that the Law of Octaves was applicable only upto calcium, as after calcium every eighth element did not possess properties similar to that of the ﬁrst.

questions.question: Which of the following group elements are called chalcogens?
questions.explanation: Group -16. They are - Oxygen (O), Sulphur (S), Selenium (Se), Tellurium (Te) and Polonium (Po), and Livermorium (Lv).

questions.question: What is the name of a metallic radioactive transuranic element with atomic number 101 in the actinide series, discovered in 1955 ?
questions.explanation: Mendelevium (Md): It is a highly synthetic and radioactive element, named after Dimtri Mendeleev (Father of the periodic table), formed by bombarding einsteinium (99) with alpha particles. Transuranic elements are members of the actinide series beginning with neptunium (93) which are artiﬁ cially produced in nuclear reactors, accelerators and all have several isotopes that emit alpha rays.

questions.question: Identify the element that does NOT belong to Period 6 of Modern Periodic Table.
questions.explanation: Silicon (Si):- Atomic number - 14 , Group - 14, Period - 3. Uses: To make alloys including aluminium - silicon and ferro - silicon (iron - silicon).

questions.question: Lanthanides are often called:
questions.explanation: Rare earth elements. Lanthanides are the elements with atomic numbers from 57 to 71. Lanthanides and Actinides are located mostly in the "f-block" of the periodic table. The f-block, also known as inner transition element, consists of elements in which 4 f and 5 f orbitals are progressively ﬁlled.

questions.question: Which element in the modern periodic table has the same number of valence electrons as that of caesium?
questions.explanation: Potassium (K, 19). Valence electrons - 1. Caesium (Cs, 55), Valence electrons - 1. Valence electrons are electrons that are located in the outermost electron shell of an atom.

questions.question: ________ is the heaviest naturally occurring element of the Periodic Table with an atomic weight of 238.
questions.explanation: Uranium. Atomic number - 92, Symbol - U. The heaviest man made element - Oganesson with atomic number 118, Atomic weight - 294, Symbol - Og. Hydrogen is the lightest element with atomic number - 1, Symbol - H, atomic weight - 1.0078. Astatine is the rarest element in Earth's crust, found only as a decay product of heavier elements.

questions.question: Which among the following is a noble chemical element of science periodic table ?
questions.explanation: Helium - It is a noble gas with Atomic number - 2, Atomic mass - 4, Symbol - He.

questions.question: Which arti ﬁ cial element has been provisionally named seaborgium by American researchers in honour of Nobel Laureate Glenn T Seaborg?
questions.explanation: Element 106. Discovery - Albert Ghiorso and named it after the Nuclear chemist Glenn T. Seaborg (1974).

questions.question: Hydrogen resembles the properties of which two groups of the periodic table?
questions.explanation: Group 1 and group 17. Hydrogen - Resembles alkali metals and halogens.

questions.question: Which element of group 13 is a soft metal with a low melting point (303K) and is widely used in doping semiconductors and producing solid-state devices such as transistors?
questions.explanation: Gallium (Ga, Atomic number: 31, Atomic mass: 69.723 u, Discovered: 1875 ). It has important uses in Blue-ray technology, mobile phones, blue andgreen LEDs and pressure sensors for touch switches.

questions.question: Who conducted X-ray spectroscopic study of a large number of elements and showed that the frequency of X-rays emitted by an element is related to the atomic number, Z, rather than the atomic mass?
questions.explanation: Henry Moseley. Lothar Meyer proposed that in arranging the elements to increase atomic weights, similarities appear in physical and chemical properties. In 1829, Johann Dobereiner recognised triads of elements with chemically similar properties, such as lithium, sodium and potassium.

questions.question: In 1955, which synthetic element is provisionally named Mendelevium in honour of Dmitri Mendeleev, who created one of the ﬁrst periodic tables?
questions.explanation: Element 101. Mendelevium (named after Dmitri Mendeleev) is a synthetic element with the symbol Md (formerly Mv).

questions.question: Which atomic number element of the periodic table is named after Alfred Nobel, the inventor of dynamite and the founder of the Nobel Prize?
questions.explanation: 102 -Nobelium (No) (radioactive element) :Relative Atomic Mass - 259 u, Block - f, Period - 7, Group - Actinide, Discovered by - Albert Ghiorso (1963). It is the tenth transuranic element.

questions.question: Which of the following elements has the largest atomic radii ?
questions.explanation: Lithium. Atomicradius is the total distance from the nucleus of an atom to the outermost orbital of its electron. It increases from top to bottom in a group and decreases from left to right across a period. Thus ,helium is the smallest element, and francium is the largest.

questions.question: Identify the group of the periodic table to which cobalt belongs.
questions.explanation: Group 9 elements - cobalt, rhodium, iridium and meitnerium.

questions.question: Which element’s symbol is derived from the Greek name hydrargyrum, meaning ‘liquid silver’ – indicating its shiny surface?
questions.explanation: Mercury (Symbol- Hg; Atomic Number- 80; Valence electrons- 2). It is used in older thermometers, ﬂuor escent light bulbs, and some electrical switches. Antimony (Sb; 51), Zirconium (Zr; 40), and Silver (Ag; 47).

questions.question: Which element of Group 13 of the periodic table lique ﬁ es just above room temperature?
questions.explanation: Gallium is one of four metals (mercury, caesium, and rubidium) that can be liquid near room temperature. Symbol- Ga; Atomic Number- 31; Valence Electrons- 3. It was discovered by French chemist Paul-Emile Lecoq de Boisbaudran in 1875. It is used in electronic circuits, semiconductors, and light-emitting diodes (LEDs).

questions.question: Identify the group of the periodic table to which iron belongs.
questions.explanation: Group 8 elements- Iron (Fe), ruthenium (Ru), osmium (Os) and hassium (Hs).

questions.question: Why does the effective nuclear charge experienced by valence electrons decrease down the group?

options.b: The outermost electrons are closest to the nucleus
options.c: The innermost electrons are farther away from the nucleus
options.d: The outermost electrons are farther away from the nucleus

questions.explanation: Metallic character decreases across a period and increases down the group.

questions.question: Of the known elements in the periodic table, only ______ are gases under normal atmospheric conditions.
questions.explanation: 11 . These elements are Hydrogen, Helium, Nitrogen, Oxygen, Fluorine, Chlorine, Neon, Argon, Krypton, Xenon, and Radon.

questions.question: Which number is called Avogadro's constant, named after the 19thcentury scientist Amedeo Avogadro?
questions.explanation: 6.022 × 1023.The Avogadro constant is 6.022 × 1023, representing the ﬁx ed number of particles (atoms, molecules, or ions) in 1 mole of any substance. This value is experimentally determined and symbolized as N A. Amedeo Avogadro {Avogadro’s hypothesis (1811) states that the total number of atoms /molecules of a gas is directly proportional to the volume occupied by the gas at constant temperature and pressure}.

questions.question: Which of the following statements best describes Le Chatelier's principle? A. The law states that the total pressure of a mixture of gases is equal to the sum of the partial pressures of the individual gases. B. The principle states that the rate of a chemical reaction is directly proportional to the concentration of the reactants. C. The principle states that a change in the variables describing a system at equilibrium causes a shift in the equilibrium position to counteract the change. D. The principle states that the volume of a gas at constant temperature is inversely proportional to its pressure.
questions.explanation: C. To determine the course of a reaction and make qualitative predictions about how changes in conditions affect equilibrium, we use Le Chatelier’s principle. This principle states that a change in any of the factors that determine the equilibrium conditions of a system will cause the system to change in such a manner so as to reduce or to counteract the effect of the change. This is applicable to all physical and chemical equilibria.

questions.question: Who, in the 1860s, undertook athorough investigation of the gas laws expressing the relationships of pressure, temperature and volume in carbon dioxide?
questions.explanation: Thomas Andrews - He was an Irish physicist and chemist who is best known for his work on the liquefaction of gases.

questions.question: Who described in 1662 that when a gas was pumped into an enclosed space, it would shrink to ﬁt in that space, but the pressure exerted by the gas on the container would increase?
questions.explanation: Robert Boyle. French physicist Jacques Charles (1746-1823) studied the effect of temperature on the volume of a gas at constant pressure.

questions.question: Which of the following is used as a cooling medium for the Large Hadron Collider (LHC) and the superconducting magnets in MRI scanners and NMR spectrometers?
questions.explanation: Helium (He). Atomic number - 2, Group - 18 (Noble gas), Block - S, chemically inert. Other uses of Helium - To keep satellite instruments cool, for arc welding, to provide an inert protective atmosphere for making ﬁbr e optics and semiconductors.

questions.question: The lowest temperature at which a substance catches ﬁr e is called its ___.
questions.explanation: Ignition temperature. Kerosene has low and coal has a high ignition temperature. Inﬂ ammable substance - Very low ignition temperature, can easily catch ﬁr e with a ﬂame. Examples - Liqueﬁ ed petroleum gas, petrol, magnesium, kerosene.

questions.question: According to which of the following laws, the pressure of a mixture of gases is equal to the sum of the partial pressures of the component gases?
questions.explanation: Dalton's Law. Charles' Law: The volume of an ideal gas at constant pressure is directly proportional to the absolute temperature. Graham's Law: The rate of diffusion of a gas is inversely proportional to the square root of its molecular weight.

questions.question: In 1662, who described the equation P1V1= P2V2, where P1and V1are the initial pressure and volume values, and P2and V2are the pressure and volume values of the gas after the transformation?
questions.explanation: Robert Boyle (Boyle’s law): Joseph Gay Lussac {Gay- Lussac's law (1808) states that the pressure exerted by a gas (of a given mass and kept at a constant volume) varies directly with the absolute temperature of the gas}.

questions.question: One mole of an ideal gas occupies a volume of ______ litre at 273 K and 1 atm pressure.
questions.explanation: 22.4litre. Theidealgaslaw, also called the general gas equation, is the equation of state of a hypothetical ideal gas. PV=nRT, Where P= Pressure, V=Volume, n=Amount of Substance, R= Ideal Gas Constant, T= Temperature.

questions.question: What is the product of the following chemical reaction? NaCl + H2O + CO2+ NH3
questions.explanation: Baking soda. The reaction between sodium chloride (NaCl), water (H2O), carbon dioxide (CO2), and ammonia (NH3) produces sodium bicarbonate (baking soda) as part of the Solvay process.The chemical equation for this reaction is: NaCl+H2O+CO2+NH,→NaHCO3+NH4Cl Here, NaHCO 3is baking soda, and NH 4Cl (ammonium chloride) is a by-product.

questions.question: Which of the following decomposition reactions is NOT a redox reaction?
questions.explanation: Decomposition of calcium carbonate. A redox reaction is de ﬁ ned as a reaction in which oxidation and reduction take place simultaneously. The decomposition of calcium carbonate (CaCO 3) into calcium oxide (CaO) and carbon dioxide (CO 2) does not involve a change in the oxidation states of the elements involved, making it a non-redox reaction.

questions.question: When electricity is passed through water, what kind of chemical reaction occurs ?
questions.explanation: Decomposition. This process is known as electrolysis which breaks down water (H2O) into its constituent gases, hydrogen (H 2) and oxygen (O 2). Reactions in which a compound splits up into two or more simpler substances are known as decomposition reactions.

questions.question: Which of the following statements is INCORRECT ?

options.a: Fats and oils get reduced over time and smell bad
options.b: Fats and oils are oxidised, they become rancid.
options.c: Antioxidants are added to foods containing fats and oil to prevent oxidation.
options.d: Chips manufacturers usually ﬂush bags of chips with Nitrogen to prevent the chips from getting rancid.

questions.explanation: When fats and oils are oxidized, they undergo a process known as rancidity, which results in an unpleasant smell and taste. This occurs because the oxidation of fats leads to the formation of compounds like aldehydes and ketones, which give rancid products their off- ﬂ avor.

questions.question: The decomposition of gaseous Ammonia on a hot platinum surface is a _________ order reaction at high pressure.
questions.explanation: zero. In this reaction, platinum serves as a catalyst. Under high pressure, the metal surface becomessaturated with gas molecules. Chemical decomposition, also known as chemical breakdown, is the process of breaking down a single chemical entity (such as a molecule or reaction intermediate) into two or more fragments. It is generally considered the opposite of chemical synthesis.

questions.question: The cause of a redox reaction is the:

options.a: transfer of electrons between two reactants
options.b: transfer of electrons between two products
options.c: transfer of neutrons between two reactants
options.d: exchange of halogens between two reactants

questions.explanation: Transfer of electrons between two reactants. 2Na(s) + S(s) → Na2S(s) are redox reactions because in each of these reactions sodium is oxidised due to the addition of either oxygen or more electronegative element to sodium. Simultaneously, chlorine, oxygen and sulphur are reduced because to each of these, the electropositive element sodium has been added.

questions.question: Which of the following gases emits red light when electricity is passed through it ?
questions.explanation: Neon. Electric discharge in gases happens when electric current passes through a gaseous medium, leading to the ionization of the gas. This process can produce visible light, with different elements emitting various wavelengths and colors as they return to their ground states. Gas and Colour : Hydrogen - Blue-violet, Helium - Pink-orange, Argon - Violet and Krypton - Lavender.

questions.question: Find out why white silver chloride turns grey in sunlight.

options.a: Due to rusting of silver in presence of oxygen
options.c: Due to the decomposition of silver chloride into silver and chlorine by light
options.d: Due to the displacement of silver chloride to silver oxide

questions.explanation: Silver chloride (AgCl) is a photosensitive compound, which means it reacts to light by decomposing. Whensilver chloride is exposed to sunlight, the energy from the light causes the compound to break down into silver and chlorine ions. The silver ions combine with other substances in the environment to form a white precipitate, which gives the appearance of the silver chloride turning white.

questions.question: Which of the following statements are true based on the 4NH3(g) + 5O2(g)→4NO(g) + 6H2O(g) ? (i) N gets oxidized. (ii) O gets oxidized. (iii) N gets reduced. (iv) O gets reduced
questions.explanation: (i) and (iv). The reaction 4NH3(g) + 5O2(g)→4NO(g) + 6H2O(g) is an example of a redox reaction, which means it involves both oxidation and reduction. The nitrogen in ammonia (NH3) is oxidized when oxygen is added. The oxygen (O2) is reduced when hydrogen is added to form water (H2O). Ammonia acts as a reducing agent. Oxygen acts as an oxidizing agent.

questions.question: Which of the following chemical reactions takes place when quicklime reacts with water?
questions.explanation: CaO(s) + H2O(l)→Ca(OH)2 (aq). This reaction is known as slaking of lime, where quicklime (calcium oxide) reacts with water to form calcium hydroxide.

questions.question: For a chemical reaction with a rise in temperature by 10°, the rate constant becomes nearly __________.
questions.explanation: Double. The rate constant is deﬁ ned as the proportionality constant which explains the relationship between the molar concentration of reactants and the rate of a chemical reaction.

questions.question: A chemical reaction in which the rate of reaction is directly proportional to the ﬁrst power of the concentration of the reacting substance is called:
questions.explanation: ﬁrst order reaction. Mathematically, this is represented as: Rate = k[A] Where: Rate is the rate of reaction, k is the rate constant, [A] is the concentration of the reacting substance. Zero-order reaction: Rate is independent of concentration (Rate = k) Second-order reaction: Rate is proportional to the second power of concentration (Rate = k[A]2)

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT a physical change?

options.a: Heating of iron rod to red hot

questions.explanation: Curdling of milk. It is a chemical change because lactic acid bacteria changes the milk permanently to the curd. A change in which a substance undergoes a change in its physical properties is called a physical change. A physical change is generally reversible. In such a change no new substance is formed. Examples include dissolving sugar in water, sublimation of dry ice, crushing paper, melting wax, and boiling water.

questions.question: When you take Lead nitrate powder in a boiling tube and heat it, you will observe the emission of brown fumes that are of ____________ .
questions.explanation: Nitrogendioxide (NO₂). When lead nitrate powder is heated in a boiling tube, the brown fumes that are emitted are of nitrogen dioxide. Chemical reaction: 2Pb(NO3)2(s)→2PbO(s)+ 4NO2(g)+ O2(g).

questions.question: The type of reaction that is typically found when a material that is required for the reaction to proceed, such as a surface or a catalyst, is saturated by the reactants is called a ________ order reaction.
questions.explanation: zero-order reaction: It is a type of chemical reaction in which the rate is independent of the concentration of reactants, remains constant regardless of reactant concentration, andis typically limited by factors other than the concentration of the reactants.

questions.question: How many carbon dioxide and water molecules will be there in the product side, if the following equation is made balanced ?
questions.source: SSC CGL 26/09/2024 (1st Shift) C2H5OH + O 2→CO 2+ H 2O
questions.explanation: 2 and 3, respectively. A chemical equation represents a chemical reaction, with reactants on the left and products on the right, using their respective chemical symbols. An equation is considered balanced when the number of each atom is equal on both sides, adhering to the law of conservation of mass. This law states that atoms of the reactants are rearranged to form products, while the total mass remains constant throughout the reaction.

questions.question: Electrochemical cell is a device which converts chemical energy into electrical energy in a/an _____.
questions.explanation: indirect redox reaction. A galvanic (or voltaic) cell is an electrochemical cell that converts the chemical energy of a spontaneous redox reaction directly into electrical energy. The Gibbs free energy from the redox reaction powers electrical work, which can be used to run devices such as motors, heaters, or fans.

questions.question: In which of the following liquids would anthracene dissolve easily ?
questions.explanation: Benzene (C6H6) - It is a colorless or light yellow liquid at room temperature. It is widely used in the production of plastics, resins, synthetic ﬁbers, rubber, and lubricants. The benzene molecule consists of alternating single and double bonds between carbon atoms, forming a total of 9 single bonds and 3 double bonds. The structure is planar, with a regular hexagonal shape and bond angles of 120º. Additionally, benzene is used as an additive ingasoline.

questions.question: The method of separating a mixture of soluble solids by dissolving them in a suitable hot solvent and then lowering the temperature slowly is called:
questions.explanation: fractionalcrystallisation. Azeotropic distillation is the process of separating all the components of an azeotropic mixture by the process of distillation. Sublimation is the change of solid state directly to gaseous state without going through liquid state.

questions.question: Which of the following is an example of a ‘solid in a liquid’ type of solution ?
questions.explanation: Tincture of iodine. Iodine tincture is considered an antiseptic. 2 - 3 % per cent solution of iodine in alcohol-water mixture is known as tincture of Iodine. A solution is a mixture formed when a solid, liquid or gaseous substance is homogeneously mixed with a liquid. Examples of solid in a liquid: Muddy water, Salt and water, Sugar solution.

questions.question: Which of the following statements best describes the Hardy Schulze rule ?

options.a: The amount of electrolyte required for the coagulation of a de ﬁ nite amount of a colloidal solution is dependent on the valency of the coagulating ion.
options.b: This is applied to obtain a colloidal solution of metals such as gold, silver or platinum.
options.c: The ions are removed from the solution by the phenomenon of diffusion through a permeable membrane.
options.d: The partial pressure of a component in a liquid mixture is proportional to its mole fraction in that mixture.

questions.explanation: The Hardy-Schulze rule states that a precipitate ion’s coagulation power increases as its valency increases. For instance, Al3+> Ba2+> Na+is the coagulation power series of Al3+, Na+, and Ba2+.

questions.question: Name the white precipitate formed in the reaction of sodium sulphate and barium chloride.
questions.explanation: Barium sulphate. Sodium Sulfate (Na 2SO 4) and Barium Chloride (BaCl 2) remain in ionic form in their aqueous solution. When the aqueous solutions of these compounds are mixed, a double displacement reaction takes place involving the exchange of chloride and sulphate ions. The product formed is a solid precipitate of Barium Sulphate (BaSO 4). The chemical equation for the reaction is: Na2SO4+ BaCl2→2NaCl + BaSO 4.

questions.question: The dry cell is made up of an outer___container that acts as the anode.
questions.explanation: zinc. A dry cell is a type of zinc-carbon battery composed of the following parts : Carbon Rod - Positioned centrally, this rod functions as the cathode. Electrolyte - A paste made of ammonium chloride surrounds the zinc anode, facilitating the ﬂow of ions. Manganese Dioxide Shield - This shield surrounds the cell, helping to improve the eﬃ ciency and longevity of the battery.

questions.question: Which process of phase transition is the reverse of deposition?
questions.explanation: Sublimation - The transition of a substance directly from the solid to the gas state, without passing through the liquid state. Examples - Ammonium chloride (NH 4Cl), iodine, camphor, naphthalene, dry ice.

questions.question: The major component of granite is:
questions.explanation: SiO2and Al2O3.Granite is a coarse-grained igneous rock composed mainly of quartz, feldspar, and mica. Quartz is a mineral made up of silicon dioxide (SiO2), and feldspar is a mineral made up of aluminium oxide (Al2O3), so these two minerals make up the majority of granite.

questions.question: At normal temperature and atmospheric pressure, ____ has a density of 1.87 kg/m3, which is 1.5 times heavier than air and exists as a liquid below thecritical temperature of 31°C.
questions.explanation: Carbondioxide is a colorless, odorless, and tasteless gas. It is non- ﬂ ammable and non-toxic. It is essential for plant life, but it is also a greenhouse gas that contributes to climate change.

questions.question: In July 2018, an experiment aboard the International Space Station cooled a cloud of atoms of which chemical element to one ten-millionth of one Kelvin above absolute zero, forming a Bose-Einstein Condensate in space?
questions.explanation: Rubidium (Rb) - An alkali and soft metal that ignites in air and reacts violently with water and has atomic number 37 in the ﬁfth period of the periodic table. Use: In the ﬁlaments of photo-electric cells that convert light energy into electric energy.

questions.question: Which odourless, colourless, tasteless and chemically unreactive gas was invented by Daniel Rutherford in 1772 and was independently isolated at the same time by CW Scheele and H Cavendish ?
questions.explanation: Nitrogen (N, 7): It is used to make fertilizers, nitric acid, nylon, dyes and explosives. Argon (Ar, 18): Discovered by Lord Rayleigh and Sir William Ramsay in 1894, It is a colourless, odourless gas that is totally inert to other substances. Fluorine (F, 9): Discovered by Henri Moissan in 1886.

questions.question: From the given options, choose the one which is NOT a product of the decomposition reaction of Lead nitrate.
questions.explanation: Nitrogen. A decomposition reaction is a chemical reaction in which one reactant breaks down into two or more products. It can be both endothermic or exothermic. Lead Nitrate Pb(NO3)2on decomposition Produces Lead oxide (PbO), Oxygen molecule (O 2), and Nitrogen dioxide (NO 2). Balanced Chemical equation - 2 Pb(NO3)22 PbO + 4 NO2+ O2. →Q.260. Which of the following statements is correct ? SSC CPO 05/10/2023 (Afternoon) (a) Zinc oxide is a form of rust (b) Chemically rust is hydrated ferric oxide (c) Chemically rust is non-hydrated ferric oxide (d) Copper can also turn into rust upon hydration Sol.260.(b) Rust is an iron oxide, a usually reddish-brown oxide formed by the reaction of iron and oxygen in the catalytic presence of water or air moisture. Rust is a Hydrated Iron (III) Oxide (Fe2O3xH2O). Rusting mainly happens on surfaces of iron and its alloys. Corrosion is a natural process that converts a re ﬁ ned metal into a more chemically stable oxide.

questions.question: The correct order of electron aﬃ nity of halogens is:
questions.explanation: I<Br<F<CI. They are very reactive, the reactivity decreases from ﬂuorine to astatine. Electron aﬃ nity is one of the periodic properties of the elements. From top to bottom electron aﬃ nity decreases, From left to right electron a ﬃ nity increases.

questions.question: What is the popular name for mercury(I) chloride which is used as a laboratory reagent and as a depolarizer in dry batteries?
questions.explanation: Calomel (Hg2Cl2). Compounds and their popular names and uses: Carbonyl Chloride (COCl2) - Phosgene used in making organic chemicals, dyestuffs, polycarbonate resins, and isocyanates for making polyurethane resins.

questions.question: Which of the following is a highly electropositive element that readily gives up an electron in order to obtain a stable electronic con ﬁ guration?
questions.explanation: Na (Sodium) - Group 1A (Alkali Metal). Electropositivity can be deﬁ ned as the tendency of an atom to donate electrons and form positively charged cations. Most Electropositive elements: Caesium. Most electronegative element - Fluorine.

questions.question: Which of the following pairs of compounds - boiling point is correct? I. Chloroform - 334K II. Methane - 111K
questions.explanation: Both I and II. Boiling Point in Celsius: Chloroform (CHCl ₃) : 61.2°C and Methane (CH 4) is -161.5°C. Some chemical elements and boiling points: Lowest boiling point element : Helium (-269°C). Aluminium (2467°C), Chlorine (-34.04°C), Bromine (58.8°C). In the absence of other intermolecular forces, the higher the molecular weight of a compound, the higher its boiling point.

questions.question: Which of the following has the highest boiling point ?
questions.explanation: Alkynes (CnH2n-2)-They have higher boiling points than alkanes and alkenes due to their stronger London dispersion forces resulting from their linear shape and increased electron density from the triple bond. Example - Ethyne (C2H2), Propyne (C3H4).

questions.question: The valency of argentic is:
questions.explanation: +2. Argentic (relating to compounds in which silver is bivalent). Valency - The combining capacity of one element with another element. It determines the number of electrons an element can donate or accept to form a stable electronic con ﬁ guration. The element that exhibits lower valency will be su ﬃ xed with “ous” while the element that exhibits higher valency will be suﬃ xed with “ic”. Silver (Ag) - Argentous (Ag⁺¹) and Argentic (Ag⁺²).

questions.question: Which of the following acids makes up 55-80% of olive oil, making it a good choice for most cooking methods?
questions.explanation: Oleic acid (C18H34O2) - A mono-unsaturated omega-9 fatty acid found in various animal (chicken and turkey) and vegetable sources (soybean oil, palm oil and corn oil); uses - An excipient in pharmaceuticals and as an emulsifying or solubilizing agent in aerosol products.Q.268. What is the atomicity of Chlorine? SSC CGL 25/07/2023 (2nd shift) (a) Tetra-atomic (b) Diatomic (c) Poly-atomic (d) Monoatomic Sol.268.(b)Diatomic . Types of Atomicity: Monoatomic - Elements which have only one atom and in which atoms do not join to form a cluster. Example: Noble gases Helium (He), Neon (Ne), Argon (Ar), Krypton (Kr). Diatomic - Elements that have two atoms. Example: Hydrogen (H2), Nitrogen (N2), Fluorine (F2). Triatomic - Elements that have 3 atoms. Example: Ozone(O 3).Polyatomic - Elements that have more than 3 atoms. Example: Sulphur (S 8), buckminsterfullerene (C60).

questions.question: Which of the following elements has variable valency ?
questions.explanation: Iron. Variable valency is the ability of an atom to form different numbers of bonds with other atoms, which is determined by the number of unpaired electrons in the atom's outermost energy level.

questions.question: Which of the following is the correct descending order of nitrate ion (NO 3–), chloride ion (CI–), bromide ion (Br–) and iodide ion (I–) as per their basic strength?
questions.explanation: NO3–>CI–>Br–>I–.

questions.question: Which among the following has the highest boiling point?
questions.explanation: CaO. Calcium oxide (Quicklime) Boiling point : 2850oC, Melting point : 2572oC.NaCl (sodium chloride) Boiling point : 1465oC, Melting point : 801oC.CaCl2(calcium chloride) Boiling point: 1935oC, Melting point : 772 oC.LiCl (lithium chloride) Boiling point: 1382oC, Melting point: 605oC.

questions.question: When an iron nail is dipped into a ______ coloured copper sulphate solution, its colour changes to ________.
questions.explanation: Blue, green. Copper reacts with the elements (oxygen, water andcarbon dioxide), it turns from its element colour of reddish-brown to green. Copper sulphate is used in Benedict’s solution and in Fehling’s solution, which is used in testing for reducing sugars.

questions.question: What is the product of a reaction of calcium carbonate, water and carbon dioxide?
questions.explanation: Calcium hydrogencarbonate {CaCO3+ CO2+ H2O→Ca(HCO3)2}. The reaction proceeds at room temperature. It is used as an antacid to alleviate heartburn, acid indigestion.

questions.question: Which gas is used by chemical leaveners, such as baking powder and baking soda, to lighten and aerate baked goods ?
questions.explanation: Carbondioxide (CO2) is used as arefrigerant, inﬁr e extinguishers, for inﬂ ating life rafts and life jackets, blasting coal, foaming rubber and plastics, promoting the growth of plants in greenhouses, immobilizing animals before slaughter, and in carbonated beverages .

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT a neutral oxide ?
questions.explanation: Na2O(Sodium oxide) - It is basic in nature. Neutraloxides are oxides which are neither acidic nor basic. Examples:- nitrous oxide (N2O), nitric oxide (NO), carbon monoxide (CO).

questions.question: Which of the following is correctly paired?
questions.explanation: Cyanide ion - CN–are chemical compounds which are fast acting poisons with a chemical formula CN−. Anammonia molecule can bind another proton (H+) and become an ammonium ion, NH4+.

questions.question: The mineral Carnotite is an important source of:
questions.explanation: Uranium.Carnotite, radioactive, bright-yellow, soft, and earthy vanadium mineral that is an important source of uranium. Carnotite is a bright to greenish-yellow mineral. The primary uranium ore mineral is uraninite (UO 2) (previously known as pitchblende).

questions.question: What is the boiling point of water at sea level?
questions.explanation: 100°C. At lower pressure or higher altitudes, the boiling point is lower. At sea level, pure water boils at 212 °F (100°C). At the lower atmospheric pressure on the top of Mount Everest, pure water boils at about 154 °F (68°C).

questions.question: Which of the following is a polar molecule?
questions.explanation: Water. Apolarmolecule is a molecule containing polar bonds where the sum of all the bond's dipole moments is not zero. Examples of Polar Molecules: Water (H2O), Ethanol (C2H5OH), Ammonia (NH 3), Sulphur dioxide (SO 2), Hydrogen sulphide (H2S).

questions.question: Which of the following options are homogeneous mixtures?

options.a: Solution, colloid, milk, toothpaste, salt water, brass
options.c: Solution, colloid, suspension, milk, toothpaste, salt water, brass

questions.explanation: Solution, salt water, brass. There are two types of mixtures: Homogeneous and heterogeneous. A mixture is a material composed of two or more simpler substances. Examples of homogeneous -air, wine, vinegar, coffee, natural gas, steel .Examples of heterogeneous - oil and water, concrete, orange juice with pulp, sandy water, cereal in milk, a sandwich, blood.

questions.question: What is the percentage composition of the element of H2SO3?
questions.explanation: 2.5%H,39%S,58.5%O.Sulfurous Acid (H 2SO 3) - Dihydrogen trioxosulphate or trioxo sulphuric acid. Mass - 82.07 g/mol. Percent composition = (mass of element / molecular mass) x 100. Composition of other compounds: Sulfuric acid (H 2SO 4) - 2.01 % H, 32.5 % S, 65.3 % O, Sodium carbonate (Na 2CO 3) - 43.40% Na, 11.32% C, 45.28% O.

questions.question: Whose research was fundamental in establishing the modern discipline known as surface tension, Which describes the properties of liquid and solid surfaces and interfaces?
questions.explanation: Agnes Pockels. Surface tension -A phenomenon in which the surface of a liquid, where the liquid is in contact with a gas, acts as a thin elastic sheet. Example : Insects walking on water, Floating a needle on the surface of the water.

questions.question: What is the ratio by mass of carbon and oxygen in carbon dioxide?
questions.explanation: 3 : 8. One atomic mass unit is de ﬁ ned as one twelfth of the mass of one carbon - 12 atom. The relative atomic masses of all elements have been found with respect to an atom of carbon-12. Carbon Dioxide (CO 2) - The atomic mass of carbon and oxygen is 12u and 16u respectively. The ratio of carbon and oxygen in Carbon dioxide (CO 2) = {12 : (16 × 2)} = (12 : 32) = (3 : 8).

questions.question: Which of the following colloid is an example of foam?
questions.explanation: Sponge. Acolloid is a mixture in which one substance microscopically dispersed insoluble particles are suspended throughout other substances.

questions.question: Which of the following is an example of emulsion?
questions.explanation: Milk. Emulsion is a mixture of two or more liquids in which one is present as droplets, of microscopic or ultramicroscopic size, distributed throughout the other. Example - Milk, Hair Cream.Aerosol- Smoke, Dust, Fog, Mist, Clouds. Gel - Cheese, Butter, Jellies.Foam - Froth, Whipped Cream, Soap Lather.

questions.question: Which of the following techniques can be used to separate the impurities in Milk?
questions.explanation: Columnchromatography is a technique that is used to separate a single chemical compound from a mixture dissolved in a ﬂuid.

questions.question: What kind of substances are separated using the technique of steam distillation?
questions.explanation: Steam distillation is a separation process that consists of distilling water together with other volatile and non-volatile components. The coarse substance feels rough and hard, used by gymnasts as it increases the friction between the bar and the gymnast's hands.

questions.question: Which of the following techniques can be used for reducing the total dissolved solids (TDS) in water? (1) Ion Exchange (2) Distillation (3) Carding
questions.explanation: Both1and2. The TDS (Total Dissolved Solids) level between 50-150 is considered as the most suitable and acceptable.

questions.question: Which among the following is NOT true about a solution and the solute concerned?

options.a: The particles of the solute do not scatter a beam of light
options.b: The particles of the solute settle down at the bottom when the solution is kept undisturbed.
options.c: The particles of the solute cannot be seen with unaided eyes.
options.d: A solution is a homogeneous mixture

questions.explanation: Only the particles of a Solute in a Heterogeneous solution settle down at the bottom when the solution is left undisturbed. In a homogenous solution the solute gets dissolved completely in the solvent. For example salt or sugar in water gets completely dissolved.

questions.question: Solubility of gases in liquids _____ with decrease in temperature.
questions.explanation: Increases. Solubility of gases in liquids increases with decrease in temperature and it decreases with the increase in temperature. Adding heat to the solution provides thermal energy that overcomes the attractive forces between the gas and the solvent molecules.

questions.question: ________ Law of independent migration of ions states that limiting molar conductivity of an electrolyte can be represented as the sum of the individual contributions of the anion and cation of the electrolyte.
questions.explanation: Kohlrausch Law is dependent on the nature of the solvent and on the potential gradient but not on the other ions present. Kohlrausch Law helps in determination of limiting molar conductivities for any electrolyte. Weak electrolytes have lower molar conductivities and lower degree of dissociation at higher concentrations.

questions.question: Which of the following contains small droplets of liquid or particles of solid dispersed in a gas ?
questions.explanation: Aerosol . Gel is a semi-solid material that is a mixture of solid particles suspended in a liquid. Vapour is diffused matter (such as smoke or fog) suspended ﬂoating in the air and impairing its transparency. Foam is a colloidal system of gas bubbles dispersed in a liquid.

questions.question: Which of the following polyhalogen compounds is used in the production of the freon refrigerant R-22 ?
questions.explanation: Chloroform (CHCl 3): IUPAC name - Trichloromethane. It is employed as a solvent for fats, alkaloids, iodine and other substances. Chronic chloroform exposure may cause damage to the liver (where chloroform is metabolised to phosgene) and to the kidneys. It is slowly oxidised by air in the presence of light to an extremely poisonous gas, carbonyl chloride.

questions.question: Which of the following gases are found in coal mines and marshy places ?
questions.explanation: Methane gas (CH 4) is produced by anaerobic decay of organic matter. Thus, it is found in biogas, coal mines, the surface of marshy lands and septic systems. It is an important component of natural gas which is widely used as a domestic fuel. It is a greenhouse gas that traps heat in the atmosphere.

questions.question: What is the adulterant of hot paprika?
questions.explanation: Sudan dye. They are synthetic chemical dyes with similar structures, characterized by an azo group (-N=N-). Adulterants are substances secretly added to compromise the safety or quality of products like food, cosmetics, and pharmaceuticals. Common examples include sand and ﬁlth to increase weight, water to dilute milk or alcohol, high fructose corn syrup in honey, roasted chicory in coffee, urea and melamine in protein products, cheaper fats replacing dairy fats, and palm or soybean oils adulterating olive oil. Even papaya seeds may be added to black pepper.

questions.question: Match List-I with List-II.List-I (Chemicalcompound)List-II (Spices) A. Curcuminoids 1. Cardamom B. 1, 8-cineole 2. Black pepper C. Eugenol 3. Turmeric D. Piperine 4. Cloves
questions.explanation: A - 3, B - 1, C - 4, D - 2. Chemical Constituents of spices :Coriander - Linalool, borneol, terpineol, cumene. Saffron - Crocins, safranal, salicylic, vanillic acid. Mustard seeds - Allyl isothiocyanate. Garlic - Allicin. Ginger - Gingerol. Cumin - Cumin aldehyde.

questions.question: Which chemical compound is present in hard plastic such as drinking water bottles and many household items?
questions.explanation: Bisphenol A (BPA). Other uses - Used in beverage containers, compact disks, plastic dinnerware, impact - resistant safety equipment, automobile parts, and toys. BPA is toxic for humans and animals. Uses of some compounds : Tri ﬂ uralin - Used as herbicide. Chrome alum - In the tanning of leather.
