questions.explanation: Edward Davies Hughes. He was elected as a fellow of the Royal Society in 1949.

questions.question: In 1950, which Russian astronomer revised the 'nebular hypothesis’, proposing that the sun is surrounded by a solar nebula consisting mainly of hydrogen and helium as well as dust?
questions.explanation: Otto Schmidt. George Gamow - "Big Bang" theory of the origin of the universe and in 1954 his studies in biology led him to suggest that the genetic code was a triplet code. Naum Idelson - Soviet theoretical astronomer and expert in the history of physics and mathematics.

questions.question: When did Louis Pasteur discover molecular chirality and observe that crystals of some compounds exist as mirror images which laid the foundation for modern stereochemistry ?
questions.explanation: 1848. Molecular Chirality - A molecule or ion is chiral if it is non-superimposable. Scientists and their discoveries: J.J. Thomson - Electron in 1897, Marie & Pierre Curie - Radium in 1898, Albert Einstein - Special theory of relativity in 1905, James Chadwick - Neutron in 1932, Dmitri Mendeleev - Modern periodic table in 1869, Henri Becquerel - Radioactivity in 1896.

questions.question: Who ﬁrst introduced the idea of a relationship between molecular geometry and the number of valence electrons in the 1940s ?
questions.explanation: Sidgwick and Powell. VSEPR (Valence shell electron pair repulsion theory) - It is used to predict the shape of the molecules from the electron pairs. Limitation - It fails to explain isoelectronic species.

questions.question: What numerical scale was introduced in 1932 that determined the electronegativity of ﬂuorine to be 4.0 ?
questions.source: SSC CHSL 17/08/2023 (3rd shift) (a) Allred - Rochow scale (b) Mulliken scale (c) Pauling scale (b) Jae scale
questions.explanation: Paulingscale. Electronegativity - A measure of the tendency of an atom to attract a bonding pair of electrons. Pauling established Electronegativity as the ‘power’ of an atom in a molecule to attract electrons to itself. The Mulliken scale is based on the properties of individual atoms.

questions.question: Which German chemist and physicist proposed that an aromatic compound must have an odd number of pairs of electrons, Which can mathematically be written as 4n + 2 (n = 0, 1, 2, 3 etc.) in 1931?
questions.explanation: Erich Huckel. Friedrich Kekule gave the Kekule structure in 1865, that is the ring structure (Benzene) with alternate double bonds. Diffraction data produced by Maurice Wilkins and Rosalind Franklin, proposed a very simple but famous Double Helix model for the structure of DNA.

questions.question: Who discovered that diborane reacts with aldehydes and ketones to produce dialkoxyboranes, Which are hydrolysed by water to produce alcohols?
questions.explanation: HC Brown: Nobel Prize in Chemistry in 1979.

questions.question: In 1995, with whom did Eric Cornell experimentally produce the ﬁrst Bose-Einstein condensate in a rare ﬁ ed gas of rubidium atoms at extremely low temperatures?
questions.explanation: Carl Wieman. Bose-Einstein condensate (5th state of matter) - A state of matter in which separate atoms or subatomic particles, cooled to near absolute zero. Other states of matter - Solid, Liquid, Gas, Plasma (4th State of matter).

questions.question: Who found an empirical relationship between the half-life of alpha decay and the energy of the emitted alpha particles in 1911 ?
questions.explanation: Geiger and Nuttall. It states that short-lived isotopes emit more energetic alpha particles than long-lived ones.

questions.question: Who received the Nobel Prize 'for his research in the stereochemistry of organic molecules and reactions' in 1975 ?
questions.explanation: Vladimir Prelog. Stereochemistry: The study of the three-dimensional arrangement of atoms in molecules and the effects of this arrangement on chemical properties and reactions.

questions.question: In which year did Antoine Lavoisier publish 'Methods of Chemical Nomenclature', which included the rules for naming chemical compounds that are still in use today?
questions.explanation: 1787. In 1774, Lavoisier (Father of modern chemistry) did many experiments investigating combustion that would discover oxygen. In 1789, he published the ﬁrst periodic table, his ﬁndings describing the law of conservation of mass. Book - “Elementary Treatise of Chemistry”, “Elements of Chemistry”.

questions.question: In 1845, which German chemist published a method for the synthesis of acetic acid, a natural product containing two carbon atoms?
questions.explanation: Adolph Wilhelm Hermann Kolbe was a major contributor to the birth of modern organic chemistry.

questions.question: The Nobel Prize in Chemistry 1951 was awarded jointly to Edwin Mattison McMillan and ______ for their discoveries in the chemistry of the transuranium elements
questions.explanation: Glenn T Seaborg. Transuranic elements are members of the actinide series beyond uranium, beginning with neptunium (atomic number 93). The last in the series is element 103 (lawrencium).

questions.question: In which year did AEB de Chancourtois organise the elements by atomic weight, by graphing the elements around a cylinder with a circumference of 16 units, corresponding to the weight of oxygen (O) ?
questions.explanation: 1862. Chancourtois prepared Vis Tellurique (an early form of the periodic table, 1862). He was the ﬁrst scientist to see the periodicity of elements when they were arranged in order of their atomic weights.

questions.question: In 1931, who recognised that an aromatic compound must have an odd number of pairs of electrons, which can mathematically be written as 4n + 2 (n = 0,1,2,3 etc.) ?
questions.explanation: Erich Huckel (1931). Two major contributions: the Debye–Huckel theory of electrolytic solutions and the Huckel method of approximate molecular orbital (MO) calculations on π electron systems.

questions.question: In 1887, the Royal Society, London gave the Davy Medal for the ‘discovery of the periodic law of chemical elements’ to ______.
questions.explanation: John Alexander Newland stated the law of octaves (1865). The lawof octaves states that every eighth element has similar properties when the elements are arranged in the increasing order of their atomic masses.

questions.question: The British physicist named Paul Dirac was known to have introduced the concept of _________ in 1930.
questions.explanation: Antiparticles are subatomic particles having the same mass as one of the particles of ordinary matter but opposite electric charge and magnetic moment. Examples are positron, antineutron, antiproton and antineutrino .

questions.question: In 1893, which Swiss chemist was the ﬁrst to understand the molecular structures of inorganic substances - chemical compounds that do not contain carbon?
questions.explanation: Alfred Werner. Sir William Ramsay discovered helium in 1895. George de Hevesy discovered (with Dirk Coster) the element hafnium in 1923.

questions.question: Who discovered three chemical elements: cerium, thorium and selenium, and devised the modern method by which one or two letters are used to symbolize elements?
questions.explanation: Jacob Berzelius. Identi ﬁ ed and named the phenomenon of catalysis, and described how chemical bonds can form by electrostatic attraction - nowadays called ionic bonding.

questions.question: In which year did Langmuir reform the Lewis concept by abandoning the idea of a stable cubical arrangement of the octet and introducing the term ‘covalent bond’ ?
Which French chemist was one of theﬁrst scientists to synthesize organic compounds such as formic acid, methane and acetylene from their elements ?
questions.explanation: MarcellinBerthelot (French) - (“Thomsen–Berthelot principle of thermochemistry”).

questions.question: In 1979, who shared the Nobel Prize with Georg Wittig for their 'development of the use of boron - and phosphorus-containing compounds, respectively, into important reagents in organic synthesis' ?
questions.explanation: Herbert C Brown. Arne Tiselius : Nobel Prize in Chemistry in 1948, "for his research on electrophoresis and adsorption analysis. Emil Fischer: Nobel Prize in Chemistry in 1902, discovered the Fischer esteri ﬁ cation. Henry Taube: Nobel Prize in Chemistry 1983, "for his work on the mechanisms of electron transfer reactions, especially in metal complexes"

questions.question: Who co-invented the device called Cyclotron in 1934 along with Ernest Lawrence to investigate the nuclear structure ?
questions.explanation: MSLivingston. A cyclotron is a device used to accelerate positively charged particles (α-particles, deuterons, etc).

questions.question: Who was credited with discovering the hydrogen isotope, or heavy hydrogen, for which he later received the 1934 Nobel Prize in Chemistry?
questions.explanation: Harold C Urey. Francis William Aston discovered that neon had two isotopes,20Ne and21Ne in 1919. Glenn Theodore Seaborg, Co-discoverer of plutonium and all further transuranium elements. Fritz Haber developed a method for producing ammonia from nitrogen and hydrogen in 1913.

questions.question: In the 1920s, who created the Left-Step Periodic Table (LSPT) of the chemical elements, basing the positions of the elements on patterns in the arrangement of electrons around the atomic nucleus?
questions.explanation: Charles Janet. Glenn Theodore Seaborg (1951 Nobel Prize in Chemistry) - Discovery and investigation of ten transuranium elements. Julius Lothar Meyer was one of the pioneers in developing the earliest versions of the periodic table of the chemical elements.

questions.question: Who showed that heating silver cyanide (an inorganic compound) with ammonium chloride (another inorganic compound) produced urea without the aid of any living organism or part of a living organism, in 1828 ?
questions.explanation: Friedrich Wohler (German chemist) known for his work in inorganic chemistry, was the ﬁrst to isolate the chemical elements beryllium and yttrium in pure metallic form.

questions.question: Which of the following represents the chemical formula for sulphur hexa ﬂ uoride?
questions.explanation: SF6.It is a colourless, odourless, non-toxic gas of high chemical stability and inertness. It is also non- ﬂ ammable and about 5 times heavier than air-one of the heaviest known gases. It is used in the electrical industry as a gaseous dielectric medium for high-voltage sulfur hexaﬂ uoride circuit breakers, switchgear. Q.402 . What is the IUPAC name of tertiarybutyl alcohol? SSC CGL 09/09/2024 (2nd Shift) (a) 2-Methylpropan-2-ol (b) 1-propylpropan-3-ol (c) 1-Methylpropan-3-ol (d) 1-ethylpropan-3-ol Sol.402.(a)2-Methylpropan-2-ol. Tertiary Butyl Alcohol, also Tert-butyl alcohol, is a tertiary alcohol used in fuels and fuel additives, intermediates and laboratory chemicals. It is a colorless oily liquid with a sharp alcohol odor.

questions.question: Which of the following is a straight-chain alkyl carboxylic acid with the chemical formula CH3CH2CH2CO2H ?
questions.explanation: Butyric acid . It is utilized in the production of various butyrate esters (e.g., methyl butyrate), which have pleasant aromas and tastes and are used as additives in foods, perfumes, ﬂa vorings, varnishes, pharmaceuticals, and disinfectants. Methanoic acid (HCOOH), Ethanoic acid (CH 3COOH), Propanoic acid (CH 3CH 2COOH).

questions.question: Identify the structural formula for magnesium hydroxide.
questions.explanation: Mg(OH) 2. Magnesium hydroxide is an inorganic compound. It is naturally found as the mineral brucite. Magnesium hydroxide can be used as an antacid or a laxative in either an oral liquid suspension or chewable tablet form.

questions.question: Milk of magnesia is a suspension of ______ in water.
questions.explanation: Magnesium hydroxide. It is an inorganic compound. As a suspension in water, it is often called milk of magnesia because of its milk-like appearance. Name of base and Found in: Calcium hydroxide - Lime water, Ammonium hydroxide - Window cleaner, Sodium hydroxide/Potassium hydroxide - Soap.

questions.question: Select the name of the hydrocarbon with a structural formula CH3-CH2-CH2-CH2- CH2- CH3.
questions.explanation: n-Hexane. It is a colorless, highly volatile liquid with a faint petroleum-like odor, commonly used as a solvent in industries like adhesives, leather, textiles, and vegetable oil extraction.

questions.question: Which of the following is the IUPAC name of m-Dichlorobenzene ?
questions.explanation: 1,3-Dichlorobenzene. Ortho- (1,2-) means the substituents are located on adjacent carbon atoms, at positions 1 and 2. Meta- (1,3-) means the substituents are separated by one carbon atom, located at positions 1 and 3. Para- (1,4-) means the substituents are opposite each other on the ring, located at positions 1 and 4. These terms are commonly used to describe the relative positions of two substituents on aromatic compounds like benzene.

questions.question: In the IUPAC name of a compound, the _______indicates the total number of carbon atoms present in the longest carbon chain belonging to the compound.
questions.explanation: Root. The su ﬃ x in IUPAC nomenclature is usually a functional group belonging to the molecule which follows the root of the name. For example, in the case of alcohols, the suﬃ x is -ol, as seen in ethanol. Preﬁ xes are added prior to the root of the compound's IUPAC nomenclature. For instance, in 2-methylbutane, methyl is the preﬁ x indicating a methyl group attached to the butane chain.

questions.question: 2-Methylpropan-2-ol is commonly known as:
questions.explanation: tert-butyl alcohol. Common and IUPAC Names of Some Alcohols : Methyl alcohol - Methanol; n-Propyl alcohol - Propan-1-ol; Isopropyl alcohol - Propan-2-ol; n-Butyl alcohol - Butan-1-ol; sec-Butyl alcohol - Butan-2-ol; Isobutyl alcohol - 2-Methylpropan-1-ol; Ethylene glycol - Ethane-1,2-diol; Glycerol - Propane - 1, 2, 3-triol.

questions.question: What is the chemical formula for butane?
questions.explanation: C4H10.Butane : Molecular mass = 58 u, Boiling point = 272.4 K, Melting point = 134.6 K.

questions.question: Identify the chemical formula of methyl chloride from the following chemicals.
questions.explanation: CH 3Cl (Methyl chloride). It is also known as Chloromethane. It is a clear, colourless gas. It has a faint, sweet odour. It is heavier than air, and it is extremely ﬂammable. It is used primarily in the manufacture of silicones, but was formerly used as a refrigerant and anaesthetic.

questions.question: In alchemy, aqua fortis is the classical name of which chemical compound that is used chie ﬂ y in the manufacture of explosives and fertilizers, and in organic synthesis?
questions.explanation: Nitric acid (HNO₃) - A colourless liquid with yellow or red fumes with an acrid odour. It is a highly corrosive liquid (Freezing point −42 °C [−44 °F], Boiling point 83 °C [181 °F]). Used: Manufacture of fertilisers, dyes, and explosives and also in the polymer industry.

questions.question: The preferred IUPAC name of Allyl bromide is:
questions.explanation: 3-Bromopropene - Organic halide used in the synthesis of polymers, pharmaceuticals, synthetic perfumes and other organic compounds.

questions.question: What is the name of the 1, 3-isomer (or meta-isomer) of benzenediol with the chemical formula C6H4(OH)2?
questions.explanation: Resorcinol. The ortho position refers to the two adjacent positions on a benzene ring. The meta position refers to the positions separated by one carbon atom on a benzene ring. The para position refers to the opposite position (separated by two carbon atoms) on a benzene ring. In view of ortho-, meta- and para-position of hydroxyl groups, benzenediol has three isomers namely catechol, resorcinol and hydroquinone, respectively.

questions.question: What is the common name for a saturated solution of calcium hydroxide widely used as a raw material in the chemical industry?
questions.explanation: Slaked lime. Calcium hydroxide [Ca(OH) 2] reacts slowly with the carbon dioxide in air to form a thin layer of calcium carbonate (CaCO3) on the walls.

questions.question: Oxolane is a synonym of which compound having the molecular formula (CH2)3CH2O ?
questions.explanation: Tetrahydrofuran (C 4H8O). Other synonyms: Butylene oxide, Tetramethylene oxide. The compound is classi ﬁ ed as a heterocyclic compound, speci ﬁ cally a cyclic ether. It is a colourless, water-miscible organic liquid with low viscosity.

questions.question: What is the IUPAC name of allylamine which is used to make pharmaceuticals and other chemicals?
questions.explanation: 2-Propen-1-Amine(C3H7N).

questions.question: The IUPAC name of an element is Unnilennium. What is the symbol of the element?
questions.explanation: Une. International Union of Pure and Applied Chemistry (IUPAC) - It is the world authority on chemical nomenclature as well as terminology. It is basically a method of naming organic compounds according to certain rules, Established - 1919, Headquarters - North Carolina (United States).

questions.question: What is the name of the chemical compound having the molecular formula which is mostly used for the 𝐶3 𝐻4𝑂 production of acrylic acid and acrylate ester ?
questions.explanation: Acrolein (C3H4O): It is a colourless to pale yellow liquid with a strong, pungent odour. Uses:- Used as a biocide to control plants, algae, molluscs, fungi, rodents, and microorganisms.

questions.question: Polyatomic positive ions often have common names ending with the suﬃ x _________.
questions.explanation: -onium. Ion - An atom or molecule with a net electric charge due to the loss or gain of electrons. Types of ions : Cation - having positively charged ions. Anions- having negatively charged ions. Monatomic - Containing only one atom. Polyatomic ion - Ion that contains more than one atom.

questions.question: What is the chemical name for ionic compound MgCl2?
questions.explanation: Magnesium chloride (MgCl2) consists of one magnesium ion (Mg2+) and two chloride ions (Cl-) in an ionic bond.

questions.question: Sodium Hydroxide is the chemical name of which of the following common substances?
questions.explanation: Caustic Soda. It is used to manufacture soaps, rayon, paper, explosives, dyestuffs, and petroleum products.

questions.question: Negative ions that consist of a single atom are named by adding the suﬃ x ____ to the stem of the name of the element.
questions.explanation: -ide.Exampleofsomeions: - Fluoride, - Oxide, - Chloride.𝐹−𝑂2−𝐶𝑙− Polyatomic positive ions often have common names ending with the su ﬃ x -onium, Example - H3O+- Hydronium, NH4+- Ammonium.

questions.question: What is the chemical name of saltpetre?
questions.explanation: Potassium Nitrate (KNO3, Saltpetre) is an ionic white crystalline salt made up of potassium ions and nitrate ions. Uses - Main constituents of gunpowder, food preservatives and additives (in meat and ﬁsh), fertilizer, and oxidizer for ﬁr eworks and rockets, etc.

questions.question: Identify the chemical formula of ammonium hydroxide.
questions.explanation: NH 4OH. Ammonium Hydroxide (ammonia water, ammoniacal liquor, ammonia liquor, aqua ammonia) (NH4OH) colourless liquid with a strong odour. Uses: Cleaning agents, chemical fertilizers, furniture darkening, etc.

questions.question: Which low-calorie sweetener has the chemical formula that is 𝐶14𝐻18𝑁2𝑂5 two hundred times sweeter than sugar?
questions.explanation: Aspartame. It is a methyl ester of aspartic acid (phenylalanine dipeptide). Uses: ingredients in beverages, dairy products, nutrition bars, desserts, chewing gum, sauces, syrups, etc. Saccharin (C7H5NO3S) - 550 times as sweet as sucrose. Sucralose (C12H19Cl3O8) - about 320 to 1,000 times sweeter than sucrose. Neotame (C20H330N2O5) - 8000 times sweeter than sucrose.

questions.question: Which of the following is an organic compound with the formula CH 3OC 6H5used as a perfume, fragrance and solvent?
questions.explanation: Anisole (methoxybenzene, CH 3OC 6H5). Toluene (C 6H5CH 3) is found naturally in crude oil, and is used in oil reﬁ ning and the manufacturing of paints. Acetophenone (C 6H5C(O)CH 3) is used for fragrance in soaps and perfumes and as aﬂa vouring agent in foods. Aniline (C6H5NH 2) used to make dyes, drugs, explosives, plastics, and photographic and rubber chemicals.

questions.question: The chemical formula of borax is .
questions.explanation: Na2B4O7.10H2O.Borax (tincal, sodium tetraborate decahydrate) is a natural mineral and a salt of boric acid. It is also known as sodium borate, sodium tetraborate, or disodium tetraborate. It can be used in the testing of cleaning agent, insecticide, water softening agent and diabetes mellitus.

questions.question: Which of the following is soda lime ?
questions.explanation: NaOH + CaO. 3 : 1 mixture of NaOH (Sodium Hydroxide) and CaO (Calcium Oxide) is called soda lime.

questions.question: Which of the following is the formula of barium peroxide
questions.explanation: BaO 2.It is an odourless, greyish-white powder. It is used as a bleaching agent, in making Hydrogen Peroxide, Aluminium welding and textile dyeing. It is a strong oxidizing agent. BaO (Barium oxide), is used as a drying agent for solvents, in cathode ray tubes, catalysts, and crown glass .

questions.question: Which of the following pair of compound names – formulas is correct ? I. Calcium oxide – Ca 2O II. Aluminium Oxide – Al 2O3
questions.explanation: Only II. Calcium Oxide (CaO), Uses - manufacturing of cement, paper, and high-grade steel. Aluminium Oxide (Al2,O3), Uses - refractories, ceramics, and polishing and abrasive applications etc.

questions.question: Calcium hypochlorite is commonly known as:
questions.explanation: Bleaching Powder (CaOCl2). Laughing gas (Nitrous oxide, N 2O) or happy gas, is a colourless, non- ﬂ ammable gas. Used in medical and dental procedures as a sedative.

questions.question: Which of the following pairs of compound names – formula is correct? I. Hydrogen chloride – H2Cl II. Hydrogen sulphide – HS2
questions.explanation: Neither I nor II. Hydrogen Chloride (HCl) used for cleaning, pickling, electroplating metals, tanning leather, and re ﬁ ning. Hydrogen sulphide (H₂S) used to produce heavy water for nuclear power plants.

questions.question: Which of the following is the correct chemical formula of sodium aluminate ?
questions.explanation: NaAlO2(Sodium Aluminate) . In water treatment it is used as an adjunct to water softening systems, as a coagulant aid to improve ﬂocculation, and for removing dissolved silica and phosphates. Sodium Aluminate is a white powder. It is used in the manufacture of milk-glass, soap and cleaning compounds.

questions.question: Identify the chemical structure for potassium hydroxide.
questions.explanation: KOH. Potassium Hydroxide (Caustic Potash) is an inorganic compound .It is used as an electrolyte in some alkaline batteries. It is used in the thickening of food. It is used in chip fabrication for semiconductors.

questions.question: Ferrum is the Latin name for ___ .
questions.explanation: Iron (Fe). Copper (Cu)- Cuprum, Zinc (Zn) - Zincum, Antimony (Sb) - Stibium, Gold (Au) - Aurum, Lead (Pb) - Plumbum, Mercury (Hg) - Hydrargyrum, Potassium (K) - Kalium, Silver (Ag) - Argentum, Sodium (Na) - Natrium, Tin (Sn) - Stannum, Tungsten (W) - Wolfram.

questions.question: Which of the following is the scienti ﬁ c name of the mineral called chromite?
questions.explanation: Ironchromiumoxide. Chromite is used as a refractory in the production of steel, copper, glass, and cement. Chromite occurs as a primary accessory mineral in basic and ultrabasic igneous rocks.

questions.question: Which of the following is the common name of a natural admixture mineral of zinc carbonate and hydrous zinc silicate?
questions.explanation: Calamine. To differentiate the minerals, they were given new names of: Smithsonite (zinc carbonate) Hemimorphite (hydrous zinc silicate).

questions.question: Who among the following coined the name oxygen for the element released by mercury oxide in 1779?
questions.explanation: AntoineLavoisier recognized oxygen as key to combustion and named it from the Greek "oxys" (acid) and "genes" (producer). He initially thought it was essential for acid formation, but later discovered its broader role in combustion and respiration. Martin Heinrich Klaproth was a German chemist who discovered uranium (1789) and zirconium (1789). Jons Jacob Berzelius discovered Thorium in 1829.

questions.question: What is the chemical formula for the compound commonly known as 'laughing gas' ?
questions.explanation: N2O.Nitrous oxide, often called “laughing gas,” is a safe and effective sedative mixed with oxygen and inhaled through a small mask over the nose to promote relaxation. Dentists may use it to enhance comfort during certain procedures.

questions.question: Calculate the oxidation number of ‘S’ in H 2S2O7
questions.explanation: 6. To calculate the oxidation number of S in H2S2O7: Assign oxidation numbers to known elements: H = +1 and O = -2 Write the equation: 2(+1) + 2x + 7(-2) = 0 ⇒2 + 2x - 14 = 0 ⇒2x = 12⇒x = 6.

questions.question: The chemical formula of glucose is C6H12O6. The weight % of carbon in glucose is:
questions.explanation: 40. Calculate the molar mass of glucose (C6H12O6) = (6 x 12) + (12 x 1) + (6 x 16) = 72 + 12 + 96 = 180 g/mol. Total mass of carbon (C) = 6 x 12 = 72 g. We Know that, Percentage by Weight = × 100𝑊𝑒𝑖𝑔ℎ𝑡 𝑜𝑓 𝑐𝑎𝑟𝑏𝑜𝑛 𝑊𝑒𝑖𝑔ℎ𝑡 𝑜𝑓 𝐺𝑙𝑢𝑐𝑜𝑠𝑒⇒ × 100 = 40 %.72 180Q.443. Which of the following is NOT a greenhouse gas ? SSC CGL 17/09/2024 (3rd Shift) (a) Methane (b) Carbon dioxide (c) Nitrous oxide (d) Nitric oxide Sol.443.(d) Nitric oxide. The greenhouse effect is a natural process that warms the Earth's surface by trapping heat from the sun. Greenhouse gases, such as methane, carbon dioxide, nitrogen dioxide, ozone, and water vapor, absorb and emit infrared radiation, functioning similarly to a greenhouse. This process is essential for maintaining the Earth's temperature and climate.

questions.question: Identify an example of plasma as a state of matter.
questions.explanation: Neonsignbulbs. Plasma is a hot, ionized gas made up of roughly equal numbers of positively charged ions and negatively charged electrons. It has distinct characteristics that differentiate it from ordinary neutral gases, making it a "fourth state of matter" (solid, liquid, gas, and plasma). Plasmas are strongly inﬂ uenced by electric and magnetic ﬁelds due to their charged particles, unlike neutral gases.

questions.question: A proton bonds to the oxygen atom of a solvent water to give a _______hydronium ion.
questions.explanation: Trigonal pyramidal. A trigonal pyramidal molecular geometry is a shape where one atom is at the top, or apex, and three atoms form a triangular base, similar to a tetrahedron. The bond angle of a trigonal pyramid is usually 109.5°. A proton is a positively charged hydrogen ion (H+). When a proton bonds to a water molecule (H₂O), the resulting ion is called a hydronium ion (H₃O+).

questions.question: Which cycle consists of sedimentary and gaseous cycles?
questions.explanation: Biogeochemical cycle. Sedimentary cycles include iron, calcium, sulfur, and phosphorus, but are imperfect as some nutrients become trapped in sediments. Gaseous cycles, involvingnitrogen, oxygen, carbon, and water, are generally considered perfect. Biogeochemical cycles describe the movement of elements and compounds across Earth's systems (Atmosphere, Hydrosphere, Lithosphere, Biosphere, and Pedosphere) and are essential for transforming matter and energy into usable forms.

questions.question: Which of the following is the main active ingredient of clove oil?
questions.explanation: Eugenol. Curcumin is the main compound found in turmeric. Malic acid is the main acid in many fruits, including apricots, blackberries, blueberries, cherries, grapes etc. Tartaric acid is an organic acid found in fruits such as bananas, grapes and tamarind, and many vegetables.

questions.question: Which phenomenon is opposite to solidi ﬁ cation?
questions.explanation: Fusion : The process by which a substance transitions from a solid to a liquid state. Solidi ﬁ cation refers to the change from a liquid or gas to a solid state. Condensation is the transition from gas to liquid, the reverse of vaporization, which is the conversion from liquid or solid to gas. Sublimation is the direct change from solid to gas without passing through the liquid phase.

questions.question: Which of the following ﬁgur es accurately depicts the inter-conversion of the three states of matter ?
questions.explanation: b. Interconversion of states of matter refers to the process where matter changes between solid, liquid, and gas states, and back, without altering its chemical composition. This physical change is in ﬂ uenced by temperature and pressure. Plasma, the fourth state of matter, is an ionized gas consisting of roughly equal numbers of positively and negatively charged particles.

questions.question: One mole of Aluminium Sulphate Al2(SO4)3contains :
questions.explanation: 12 moles of oxygen atoms. This is because each sulfate ion (SO 4 )2- has 4 oxygen atoms, and since there are 3 sulfate ions in the formula, the total is 3 × 4 = 12 oxygen atoms.

questions.question: Which inert gas is used in double-glazed windows to ﬁll the space between the panes?
questions.explanation: Argon. Argon is used in double-glazed windows because it has low thermal conductivity, which enhances the insulating properties of the window. This helps to reduce heat transfer, making the windows more energy-e ﬃ cient by minimizing heat loss in the winter and heat gain in the summer.

questions.question: Gases, especially oxygen and carbon dioxide, are essential for the survival of aquatic animals and plants. The gases from the atmosphere reach the aquatic animals and plants through:
questions.explanation: Diffusion - It is the movement of molecules from a region of higher concentration to a region of lower concentration, down the concentration gradient. Other applications : Water present in the soil diffuses into plants through their root hair cells; Carbon dioxide moves from cells into the blood. Condensation - Change of the state of matter from the gas phase into the liquid phase. Example - Formation of Rain droplets. Evaporation - Changes of liquid to gaseous states. Sublimation - Conversion of solid to gaseous states.

questions.question: To check the presence of adulterated sugar solution in honey, a cotton wick dipped in the sample is ignited with a match stick. Adulteration is conﬁ rmed if:

options.a: it burns with a violet coloured ﬂame
options.c: it burns with a green coloured ﬂame
options.d: it burns with a crackling sound

questions.explanation: It burns with a crackling sound. Honey is composed of water and two types of Sugars (fructose andglucose). Adulterant means any material employed for the purpose of adulteration. To assess the authenticity of Turmeric powder, mix a teaspoon of haldi with water; genuine Turmeric settles at the bottom, displaying a pale yellow hue, while adulterated Turmeric turns dark yellow in water.

questions.question: At standard temperature and pressure (STP), the value of temperature is:
questions.explanation: 0°C (273.15 K or 32 degrees Fahrenheit). Standard temperature and pressure (STP) refers to the nominal conditions in the atmosphere at sea level. The standard pressure is 1 atm (atmospheric pressure). At STP , one mole of any gas will have a volume of 22.4 litres.

questions.question: Synthetic ﬁbr es, elastomers, polymers and surfactant intermediate are all subgroups of ________ industries.
questions.explanation: Petrochemical. Synthetic ﬁbr es: Man-made materials composed of polymers, such as textiles. Elastomers: Polymers with high elasticity and ﬂexibility , commonly used in products like rubber bands and tires. Polymers: Large molecules formed by the repeated linking of smaller units (monomers), often used to create diverse materials such as plastics, rubber, and ﬁbr es.

questions.question: The synthesis of which chemical is inhibited due to aspirin?
questions.explanation: Prostaglandins : It stimulates in ﬂ ammation in the tissue and causes pain. These drugs are effective in relieving skeletal pain such as that due to arthritis. Histamine - A neurotransmitter and a regulator of gastric acid secretion. It is released from Basophil and Mast cell.

questions.question: Which of the following tests is used for starch detection?
questions.explanation: Iodine test. The light orange-brown colour Iodine solution turns blue-black in colour when it reactswith starch. This indicates the presence of carbohydrates in the food item to which iodine solution was added. Example : If Iodine is added to a peeled potato then it will turn black.

questions.question: Which of the following statements best describes the characteristics of a crystalline solid ?

options.b: There is no precise melting point
options.d: Changes abruptly from solid to liquid when heated

questions.explanation: Crystalline solids - They exhibit anisotropic properties, varying in electrical resistance and refractive index values across different directions within the same crystals. Examples: Quartz, calcite, sugar, mica, diamonds, snow ﬂ akes, rock, calcium ﬂuoride, silicon dioxide, and alum.

questions.question: Which of the following correctly represents the number of atoms in one mole of CH3OH ?
questions.explanation: 3.6 × 1024.Given, One mole of methanol contains 6 atoms, including 4 moles of hydrogen atoms, 1 mole of oxygen atoms, and 1 mole of carbon atoms. So C = 1, H = 3 + 1 or 4, O = 1. 1 mole of atoms corresponds to Avogadro's number of atoms which is 6.02 × 1023. 6 mole of atoms = 6 × 6.02 × 1023 ⇒6 mole of atoms = 36.12 × 1023 ⇒6 mole of atoms = 3.6 × 1024.

questions.question: Which of the following chemical compounds, that is used as a food preservative in some sauces and beverages, retains their natural colour and protects against bacteria?
questions.explanation: Potassium metabisulphite. Other Food Preservatives - Sodium benzoate, calcium propionate, and potassium sorbate. m - Dihydroxybenzene (Resorcinol) : Uses - Manufacture of resins, plastics, dyes, medicine and other organic chemical compounds. Hydrazine hydrate is used as a reducing agent, blowing agent, corrosion inhibitor, oxygen scavenger or intermediate of synthesis. Monosodium glutamate is a ﬂa vour enhancer in foods.

questions.question: ______ is the process of complete or incomplete oxidation or hydrolysis of fats and oils when exposed to air, light, moisture, or bacterial action that spoils food.
questions.explanation: Rancidi ﬁ cation (Examples - Milk becomes rancid because of not heating it in the humid atmosphere, Oil becomes rancid (rancid oil) because of the decomposition of fats it has).

questions.question: Which of the following is the correct Lewis structure of O3?
questions.explanation: Lewis structure: A graphical representation of a molecule, showing the arrangement of atoms and valence electrons using dots to depict bonding and lone pairs. The O3molecule has no net charge, the Lewis structures reveal a +1 charge on the central oxygen and a -1 charge on the singly bonded oxygen.

questions.question: Which of the following is a synthetic ﬂuorinated compound with an extremely stable molecular structure known to be the most potent greenhouse gas ever found ?
questions.explanation: Sulphur hexa ﬂ uoride (SF 6). It is a colorless, odorless, non - ﬂammable, non - toxic gas and an inorganic gas made up of sulphur and ﬂuorine used in electrical switchgear, transformers, and substations as an electrical insulation, arc quenching and cooling medium. Other Greenhouse Gases - Carbon dioxide (CO2), Methane (CH4), Nitrous oxide (N 2O), Fluorinated gases such as Hydro ﬂ uorocarbons, perﬂ uorocarbons, sulphur hexa ﬂ uoride and nitrogen triﬂ uoride.

questions.question: How is the molecular weight of fatty acid determined?
questions.explanation: Saponi ﬁ cation value - It is the number of milligrams of potassium hydroxide (KOH) required to neutralize the fatty acids obtained by complete hydrolysis of one gram of fat or oil.

questions.question: Galvanisation is a process in which a protective _______ coating is applied on iron to prevent it from rusting.
questions.explanation: Zinc. Galvanization protects steel and iron from rusting and is commonly used in construction, pipes, and automotive parts to prevent corrosion, while adding a small amount of carbon to pure iron increases its strength and hardness.

questions.question: _________ is a process in which natural rubber is treated with sulphur to make it more durable and elastic.
questions.explanation: Vulcanisation. This process was discovered by Charles Goodyear. Saponi ﬁ cation is the process of converting fats and oils into soap. Fermentation is the process of converting sugar into alcohol or other products. Carbonation is the process of dissolving carbon dioxide in a liquid.

questions.question: Which among the following is a cooking procedure in which the sugar in the food gets oxidized, turning into a brown colour?
questions.explanation: Caramelisation. Emulsi ﬁ cation is the process of breaking down fat into smaller blood cells so that enzymes can operate and food may be digested more easily. Filtration is de ﬁ ned as the process of separating suspended solid matter from a liquid, by causing the latter to pass through the pores of a membrane.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a technique or a step to convert normal water to potable water?
questions.explanation: Bromination - Oxidation of hydrobromic acid by hydrogen peroxide in the absence of any transition metalcatalyst. It is used as ﬁr e retardant.

questions.question: What type of isomerism exists in compounds containing two or more complexes, each of which contains a different set of ligands that can in principle be replaced with a ligand of the other complex?
questions.explanation: Coordination isomerism. [Co(NH3)6][Cr(CN)6] is a coordination isomer with [Cr(NH3)6][Co(CN)6]. Ionization isomerism involves the exchange of ions inside and outside the coordination sphere. An example of ionization isomerism is [Co(NH3)5SO4]Br and [Co(NH3)5Br]SO4. Solvate (Hydrate) isomerism are the isomers which have the same composition but differ with respect to the number of solvent ligand molecules as well as the counterion in the crystal lattice.

questions.question: How many anions surround a sodium ion in a crystal lattice of sodium chloride?
questions.explanation: Six. Sodium chloride crystal (NaCl), where ions taking part are Na+ and Cl-. They have 1:1 stereochemistry and thus the coordination number of 6.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a natural ﬁbr e?
questions.explanation: Rayon. Examples of Natural ﬁbr es (Fibres obtained from natural sources like plants and animals) include : Cotton, Silk, Wool, Linen, Jute and Hemp. Examples of Arti ﬁ cial ﬁbr es (Fibres which are manufactured in laboratories) include Rayon, Nylon, Polyester, Acrylic and Aramid.

questions.question: What test is used where the elements present in the compound are converted from covalent form into the ionic form by fusing the compound with sodium metal?

options.d: Lassaigne’s test Sol.472.(d )Lassaigne's test helps to detect Nitrogen, Sulphur, and Halogens in organic compounds. A ﬂame test is a qualitative analysis used by the chemist to identify the metal and metalloid ion in the sample. A D-dimer test is a blood test that can be used to help rule out the presence of a serious blood clot.

questions.question: Carbon monoxide contains approximately ______ of oxygen for each 1.00 g of carbon.
questions.explanation: 1.33 g. Every sample of carbon monoxide contains 16.0 g of oxygen for every 12.0 g of carbon. Carbon Monoxide is used in the puriﬁ cation of nickel. It is used as a reducing agent. It is used in water gas shift reactions to produce hydrogen.

questions.question: As per WHO (World Health Organization), which of the following is NOT an example of disinfection by-products formed at traditional drinking water treatment plants?
questions.explanation: Titania. Titanium dioxide, also called titania, (TiO 2), a white, opaque, naturally occurring mineral existing in a number of crystalline forms, the most important of which are rutile and anatase. It is used in paints, coatings, papers, inks, toothpaste, face powder, and food colouring.

questions.question: How many pollutants are included to measure the Air Quality Index in India?
questions.explanation: 8. pollutants namely particulate matter (PM) 10, PM 2.5, Ozone (O 3), Sulphur dioxide (SO 2), nitrogen dioxide (NO2), carbon monoxide (CO), lead (Pb) and ammonia (NH 3) act as major parameters in deriving the AQI of an area.

questions.question: Topaz is a ______ of ﬂuorine and aluminium.
questions.explanation: Silicate.Topaz {Al₂SiO₄(FOH) ₂} is used as a gemstone in jewellery and other adornments.

questions.question: Which of the following is a weak electrolyte?
questions.explanation: Ethanoicacid. Acetic acid(CH3COOH), also called ethanoic acid, is the most important of the carboxylic acids. Ethanoic or acetic acid is used in making dyes, pigments, and paint, and coating additives.

questions.question: Iron nails become ______ after being dipped in copper sulphate solution.
questions.explanation: Brownish. Iron Nail is Fe and blue copper sulphate is CuSO 4. When nail is kept in it, Fe being more reactive than copper, it displaces copper from Copper sulphate and forms Ferrous Sulphate which is greenish blue, and the copper displaces deposits around nails giving it colour of reddish brown.

questions.question: What is the meaning of the Greek origin word, ‘Elektron’ ?
questions.explanation: Amber , the yellow fossilized resin of evergreen trees, a "natural plastic material" already known to the ancient Greeks.

questions.question: __________ is the in ﬂ ammatory compound in pepper spray.
questions.explanation: Capsaicin . It causes burning, pain and tears when it comes into contact with a person’s eyes.

questions.question: Which of the following is used to remove the green colour from glass?
questions.explanation: Manganesedioxide. Sodium Permanganate is produced by using Manganese dioxide to remove green from glass that results from the presence of Iron.

questions.question: ______ solids are formed by the three-dimensional arrangements of cations and anions bound by strong coulombic (electrostatic) forces.
questions.explanation: Ionic. They have very high melting point and are poor conductors in the Solid state. Example of ionic solid istable salt.

questions.question: In a galvanic cell, the half-cell in which oxidation takes place is called ______ and it has a negative potential with respect to the solution.
questions.explanation: Anode.Oxidation takes place at anode. And reduction happens at the cathode in a galvanic cell. Since the reaction at the anode is the source of electrons for the current, the anode is the negative terminal of the galvanic cell.

questions.question: NPK is a:

options.a: Fertilizer used for increasing fertility of soil
options.d: Sanitizer used to clean dusty leaves

questions.explanation: NPK stands for “Nitrogen, Phosphorus and Potassium”, the three nutrients that compose complete fertilizer.

questions.question: Which of the following can be used as a catalyst in Hydrogenation reaction?
questions.explanation: Palladium. Hydrogenation is a chemical reaction between molecular hydrogen (H2) and another compound or element, usually in the presence of a catalyst such as nickel, palladium, or platinum.

questions.question: Name the densest stable element known on earth.
questions.explanation: Osmium has ablue-grey tint and is the densest stable element, it is approximately twice as dense as lead and slightly denser than Iridium.
